charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
The Cotswold 24 Hour Race is held at the Bathurst Estate, just outside Cirencester. The race starts at midday on Saturday 4th August and competitors run as many laps of the 9km course (5.6 miles) as they can before midday on Sunday 5th.

I can’t really remember why I ended up doing this race as I don’t really like running, but it had something to do with David Goggins, raising money for Sightsavers (makes doing really stupid events seem less stupid) and finding out if I could actually run 100 miles in 24 hours.

There are many factors that influence the success of a 100-mile run, but I would say that two of the main ones, at least for me, are the course and the weather. The Cotswold 24 Hour Race course is described as “an off-road, 9km mixed course including forest trails and open tarmac paths”. In the world of running, the term “trail” has a pretty broad meaning, encompassing everything from flat, smooth, maintained, wood-chip covered paths, to uneven, off-camber-rock-strewn-pot-holed -ankle-twisting-leg-breaking-unrunnable-mountains. I have a permanent ankle injury (gross instability of the left ankle) so have been advised not to run on uneven surfaces; I was hoping the course was as flat and as even as it’s possible for a trail to be. (NB: There is absolutely no reason why I couldn’t have recced the course before the event and found out exactly how even/uneven it was, but I didn’t – big oversight on my part.)

There’s not much you can do about the weather and really it is part of the challenge. But this weekend the weather would be particularly challenging, because the forecast was “fricking boiling”.

These kinds of events are always more fun if you know some other people who are taking part, and I am lucky enough to be friends with Claire Smith (UK’s top female ultra-endurance athlete, 7th woman in the world to complete a Deca Ironman triathlon), who had done the race twice before. Claire would be using the race as training for a Quin Triathlon at the end of August, which in turn would be training for another Deca Triathlon in November (I’m not making this up). Claire is vastly experienced with ultra-distance racing, and her help with pacing would be crucial towards the end of the race. Paul (a friend since school) was also running, but as he’d done a lot less training than me he had not set a target mileage and was just going to see how far he could go. Another good friend, Baljinder “B-Real” BoSingh, a Doctor of Emergency Medicine, would be crewing for me and making sure I didn’t die.

My parents dropped off Paul and I at the Solo Competitor camping ground and we put up Paul’s mega tent. Hopefully we wouldn’t need it, but it’s good to have somewhere to stash all the gear and get out of the elements if required. B-Real arrived around 10:00am and Claire turned up soon after. B-Real told us how little sleep he’d had over the past few days, working long shifts in A&E and looking after his 1-year-old son who was determined to stay awake. As is always the case with me and racing, my brain had decided that I didn’t need any sleep either, and had kept me awake the entire night. Obviously, staying awake for 24 hours is not enough of a challenge, let’s make it 48. Thanks a lot, brain.

The race started on time and off we went, lap number 1. My plan was to try and get the first 50 miles (9 laps) completed in 10 hours. This would leave me with 6 hours for the next 25 miles and 8 hours for the final 25. The first lap would tell me if my plan was going to work or not.

The whole course is very scenic, but I quickly found that with my wobbly ankle I would not be able to run a lot of it. The first 3km go through woods and around fields, but the surface was pretty uneven: stones, roots, lumps and bumps. Then a runnable section of dirt road up to the first aid station, at the top of the ornamental drive looking down towards Cirencester Parish Church tower. The ornamental drive is a smooth tarmac surface that slopes downhill, but in some places too steep to run, especially if I want to make my legs last 100 miles. At the bottom of the drive there is another tarmac section just past 5km that can be run… until it turns steeply uphill, and it’s back to walking for another 100 metres or so. Although the road still slopes up hill, it’s possible to run up to about 6.5km before the course turns off into a field. After that it’s a rough-but-runnable section of single track to approximately 7.5km, then approximately 500 metres through a field before the route turns back on to a broken single-track road. Kilometre 8 to the finish is runnable.

The first lap took just over 51 minutes which was on pace for the target of 50 miles in the first 10 hours, but I was slightly concerned about the sections I had ran on that lap which I knew I would not be able to run on future laps. My other concern was the intense heat; the aid stations only supplied water, and I would need to be consuming a lot of electrolytes to replace those lost through sweating. I had planned on carrying 400ml of electrolyte drink per lap, filling my bottle at the half-way point with water, then topping up with electrolytes at the end of each lap which B-Real was mixing up for me. I had drunk all my electrolytes in the first 3km and was feeling pretty thirsty before I even got to the aid station just short of 4km. After a couple of laps, I told B-Real to double the strength of the electrolyte mix and give me two 600ml bottles to carry. I was now drinking over 2 litres of fluid per hour, I was bathed in sweat, and it felt like it was getting hotter.

I had bought a lot of food for the event, but I quickly found the only solid food I could eat was half a banana each lap. I took a “lemon meringue flavoured” gel (they don’t taste like any lemon meringue pie I’ve ever eaten, but I could at least keep them down) each lap at the halfway point. Apart from not wanting to eat, I wasn’t feeling too bad.

By lap 5 I had established a pretty consistent run/walk strategy, and with one marathon completed I was cautiously optimistic about my 50 miles in 10 hours target. It was still very hot, but my legs were feeling ok.

I stopped to do a blister check after 7 laps (just after 7:00pm) and found that my feet were black with dirt. I washed my feet and, in the process, found a blister on my big toe. I drained the blister and wrapped the toe in surgical tape, put on some fresh socks and consulted B-Real on the next issue that was slightly concerning me; even though I was drinking gallons, I hadn’t needed to pee. I was sweating freely and showing no signs of dehydration or cramping, but even so…. we made a note to monitor the pee situation.

The sun started to go down on lap 8. Although running would be harder once it got dark, at least it would be cooler. I picked up a t-shirt and headtorch from B-Real at the end of the lap and set off again. By 10:00pm I had covered 50 miles, but I’d also drank over 20 litres of fluid and still hadn’t needed to pee. Although I felt more-or-less fine, was there something wrong with my kidneys? Could I really have lost 20 litres of water through sweating alone? Sometime after 11:30pm normal service was resumed and I was rewarded with a new tune to sing in my head for the next few laps. The song was “I can see clearly now the rain has gone”, but the lyrics had morphed into “I can pee clearly now the sun has gone, I pee on all obstacles in my way”. To my sleep deprived, banana-and-gel fuelled brain this was hilarious, and I felt surprisingly good for the next couple of laps.

By lap 12 my legs were pretty sore and I was having trouble bending them. Although I could still run, the difference in speed between running and walking was negligible. By now every step hurt, but running hurt the most so it made sense to try and walk as fast as possible and hope that I still had enough in my legs to make up time at the end. I started calculating times in my head for each kilometre, each lap, how much time there was left… if I kept walking at my current pace, I wouldn’t complete 100 miles within the 24-hour cut off. Even though it would hurt, I knew I could still run - but I didn’t know how long I’d be able to keep it up, so I’d have to save my legs until the end. The last few laps were going to be as much about pain management as they would be about running.

At some point during the night I started to get cold, so stopped for more layers, a woolly hat, and to treat a few more blisters. I use Topo Athletic running shoes, the best shoes I’ve ever ran in. I had been completely blister-free in training, but the problem with running 100 miles is that the feet you start with are not the feet you finish with. A combination of dirt, sweat, swollen feet, uneven surfaces and the general attrition of taking thousands and thousands of steps were taking their toll. Needles, surgical tape and anti-septic gel would get me back on course, as long as I had B-Real to help me stand up again after I’d sat down.

The sun came up at the start of lap 15. I’d hoped to complete as many laps as possible before the heat picked up again. 80 miles done, 20 to go, and I now need to make up some time. Despite my sore feet I stomped around lap 16, knowing that Claire would help with the pacing on the penultimate lap. We started lap 17 with 3 hours and 3 minutes until cut off. I told Claire I needed to finish this lap in 1 hour 30 minutes to have enough time for lap 18. We completed the lap in 1 hour 30 minutes and 10 seconds. I have no idea how she does that.

For the final lap I was joined by Dr B-Real, who was clearly pleased to be moving again, having spent most of the past 23 hours standing around looking out for me. Unfortunately I had to apologise that I wouldn’t really be able to talk much, as all my concentration would be taken up with placing every step as carefully as possible to limit the risk of a trip/stumble/strain that could end my race, and managing the pain in my legs and feet. B-Real was great, carrying my bottles and keeping me topped up with food and drink, and could easily match my pace; 90+ miles certainly takes it out of you. We made the turn at the bottom of the ornamental drive in front of Cirencester Parish Church tower and ran to the 5km marker. I was surprised that my legs responded pretty well, and it actually felt like I was running with my own legs rather than legs I’d borrowed off someone else who had left them in a shed for a few years.

Some more walking on the steep part of the hill, then back to running. Once again, I was surprised that I could actually run – it hurt, but it wasn’t unbearable. I put my head down and kept going until 6.5km. I had been checking time/pace for each kilometre, but probably due to sleep deprivation and not being very good at maths, I’d calculated that I only had a minute in hand (we needed to cover each kilometre in exactly 10 minutes, but I had added an extra 10 minutes for kilometre 9… which is the finish, so clearly I didn’t need to run an extra kilometre after that). I kept an eye on the watch and ran all the runnable sections. By 8km I’d stopped looking. There was nothing for it now but to run.

I entered the finishing straight and crossed the line in a time of 23:48:05, having covered a total of 100.6 miles. Only in the last few hundred meters did I realise that I actually had almost 12 minutes spare, rather than the 2 minutes I thought I had. Still, none of that mattered once I’d crossed the finish line – hugs all round, and a question answered: yes, I can run 100 miles in under 24 hours… just.

Huge thanks:

B-Real, Claire Swear, The A Man, Dr Banner and The HULK, and of course Ma & Pa Dales, for all the support. Everyone involved in organising, marshalling and every other aspect of running the Cotswold 24 Hour Race. Brilliantly done. Everyone at Sightsavers for the fantastic work they do. Everyone who donated; the total money raised at time of writing is enough to cure over 350 people of blindness caused by trachoma, so many, many thanks.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Sightsavers work to eliminate avoidable blindness and promote the rights of people with disabilities. Sightsavers are trying to eliminate trachoma, the world’s leading infectious cause of blindness: 

https://www.sightsavers.org/protecting-sight/ntds/what-is-trachoma/

TED-of-the-day talk:

https://www.sightsavers.org/news/2018/06/ted-of-the-day/

In short, trachoma starts off as a bacterial infection that’s a bit like conjunctivitis and can be easily treated. However, if left untreated it causes scarring to the eyelid that makes the eyelashes turn inward, and with every blink they scrape against the eye. This causes intense pain, and over time, blindness.

Trachoma has been eliminated in many parts of the world, so the plan is to wipe it out in the 43 countries that still count trachoma as a public health problem.

To raise money to fight trachoma, I am going to try and run non-stop for 24 hours at the Cotswold 24 hour race:

https://www.100milerun.com/cotswold-24-hour-race/

Any distance over 52 miles will be a new personal best for me, but my goal is to run 100 miles or more. It's going to hurt, but if I hit my donation target it will be worth the pain. In June 2018, Ghana made history as the first country in sub-Saharan Africa and the Commonwealth to eliminate trachoma, so the campaign has already had great success.  

£8.00 pays for trachoma operations to stop two people going blind. Any donation, large or small, will help to end trachoma for good.

Many thanks,

Matthew

story:

DRAW DATED EXTENDED. Since there are still some pledges for this fundraising Raffle I have postponed the draw until tomorrow evening,17 November. Thank you so much for many donations received so far, big and small. The target amount was raised in less than a week.

Donating £2 or more enters you into the raffle to to win an original Este MacLeod created from the 'tell me a story' template as used for the #Lettergardens drawing project, #Big Draw 2105. For every £2 donated you will get a virtual raffle ticket. The hope is to raise £300 for this important charity. Sight is so important, and all too often taken for granted.  100% of donations for Sightsavers, a charity focussing on curing blindness, a condition that can be prevented in many. See more info on http://www.sightsavers.org/



The winner of the painting will have it shipped at no additional cost, regardless of location.



More about the drawing project that inspired this painting: #lettergardens, I'm inviting everyone around the world to take part in creating a flower garden drawing using the letters as printed on a downloadable template.The project is happening in several schools and youth clubs in the UK, at Windsor Contemporary Art Fair and globally. On World Kindness day Friday 13 November the artworks are to be given to someone to colour in. Share your creation on Instagram #lettergardens #thebigdraw #exploredrawing.

For more information on the project see http://blog.estemacleod.com/2015/10/drawing-with-letters.html

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

There are 39 million blind people in the world today. Out of these, 80% could have been prevented or cured, but due to a lack of available healthcare and research, over 31 million people will never see again.   

By donating to this page, you will help SightSavers to prevent thousands of cases of blindness across the world by not only offering eye checks and treatment to those who need it, but by working with national governments to tackle the causes leading to preventable blindness.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page

As we are getting married in South Africa my (Alex's) grandparents were unable to attend. Nan and grandad have been second parents to us growing up and their house was always filled with happiness and kindness. They first met when they were 14, continued to live a happy loving life at 88 and are an inspiration to us on our wedding day. It is important to us that they are a part of our day and so we asked them to pick a charity that meant something to them. Grandad picked Sightsavers straight away. He couldn't believe, that for so little money, children all over the world could have their vision returned and yet so many were still left blind and vulnerable. He had already donated to this cause himself.

13 days after grandad picked this charity for us, on 13th July 2018, he passed away surrounded by many people that loved him. Grandad's life was lived with love, kindness and generosity and it seems fitting that we should be remembering him by giving to a cause that meant a lot to him. Please give generously for us in his honour.

Grandad you will be missed but it's hard to be too sad when someone lived such a great life and touched so many people.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Sightsavers is a much needed charity that operates across developing countries to prevent blindness.  Living in the developed world we  are incredibly lucky not to have to worry about the issues being tackled by Sightsavers.

There are 12 million people who are blind due to cataracts - this is entirely preventable, but in developing countries the medical help is not always available.  With the cataracts operation costing just £30 this should not happen in 2018.

They also work to fight several tropical diseases that cause blindness, including Trachoma and River Blindness.  The treatment for these is tablets - Sightsavers work to supply these around the world.

To help this charity I'm going to swim across the English Channel.  It's about 34 km (21.5 miles) across, and to add interest no wetsuits are allowed.  Some people smother themselves in goose fat, but surely that just attracts sharks, so I'll not be doing that.  Jellyfish are common - just have to be lucky to avoid those little monsters.  Crossing one of the world's busiest shipping lanes will add a few ups and downs to carry me along my way. 

Mostly I hope just to make it to France.  I don't have a target time, but expect to be swimming around 12 - 14 hours. 

My training has mostly been eating chocolate to build up fat to keep me warm, and I've done quite well - putting on 12kg since Christmas - I hope I can lose it after!  I've also been practicing swimming with plenty of long steady (slow) hours done in the pool.

I'll be swimming on my own, but there will be a boat next to me to keep me pointing in the right direction and to throw bottles of drink at me. 

Thanks very much for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page and for reading this far.

I would be really grateful if you would sponsor me for this swim.  The money you donate will go straight to Sightsavers and will be well spent on the issues mentioned.

Thanks a lot,

Philip.

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Phoebe was born with very dense cataracts covering  both eyes, at just 8 weeks old she underwent surgery to both eyes. With fantastic opthalmolagists looking after her, she has been given the very best chance in leading her life with vision. 

We are fortunate enough to have access to an amazing eye hospital and fantastic doctors who have taken care of Phoebe since she was born. Sadly, not everyone is as lucky and there are children in the underdeveloped world, who’s sight cannot develop without this surgery. 

We want to pay it forward and help as many children who aren’t as fortunate as our little girl.

Cataracts are the leading cause of blindness around the world. £5 is all it takes to give the gift of sight to a child.

Our initial goal is to support  children around the world and give them the same chance to regain their vision as we were able to do for Phoebe.

Your donations are very much appreciated and will go directly to sightsavers. You’ll get some lovely homemade cake in return 🍰❤️🍰

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
What's my challenge?

  • I'll be trekking up Mount Kilimanjaro (Tanzania) ideally to the summit at 5.895km above sea level (and down again) this June, 2018, covering about 62km over 6 days and 5 nights. Challenge accepted!

Which charity am I fund raising for?

  • Sightsavers.  A UK registered charity founded in England in 1950.
  • I've been donating to Sightsavers for a couple of years.
  • All donations will go to Sightsavers - I will be paying all expenses, either directly or through Action Challenge which will be organising the trek.

What does Sightsavers do?

  • Sightsavers aims to prevent avoidable blindness by funding operations for people who need them, training eye care workers and surgeons. Through community volunteers in developing countries, Sightsavers arranges for medication to be distributed to prevent blinding diseases. Treating among other conditions:
  • cataracts - in developing countries it’s a huge problem for children (as well as older people) - cataracts are thought to cause up to 60% of blindness in parts of Africa, and 20 million people worldwide are blind because of the condition,
  • neglected tropical diseases (parasitic and bacterial infections that affect more than a billion people worldwide, causing severe and often lifelong physical impairment and affect some of the world’s poorest people, trapping them in a cycle of poverty and social isolation),
  • refractive errors.
  • Sightsavers also supports equality for people with disabilities and campaigns and advocates for change.
What will the trek entail?

  • Day 1: trek 11km through lush rain forest to Machame camp at 3km above sea level. 
  • Day 2: trek 5km across moorland but gaining altitude by making camp at 3.8km above sea level. 
  • Day 3 entails an 11km trek across barren semi-dessert, reaching 4.6km in altitude before descending to 4km to make camp. 
  • Day 4: after a 9km trek we sleep at Barafu Camp at 4.7m high (“barafu” being Swahili for “ice”). 
  • Day 5: starting at midnight, we start the 5km trek to the Uhuru Peak (Swahili for “freedom”) 5.9km above sea level to see the sun rise, before descending to camp for the last night on Kilimanjaro.
  • Day 6: descending down the Mweka route to a well deserved beer and much needed shower!

How your donation can help?

  • For every £1 Sightsavers receives, including donated supplies, 91p goes on vital charity work and the remainder helps grow awareness and funding.
  • £5 could help 14 people for trachoma, 
  • £28 could protect a whole community against river blindness, 
  • £50 could provide a cataract operation to restore a childs sight.
﻿﻿And finally...

  • whilst I’m concerned about how I’ll handle the altitude on Kilimanjaro, I think my biggest challenge will be the fund raising. 
  • Thank you kindly for making time to visit my fund raising page (and reading my “essay”) and donating to Sightsavers to help make a change. 

Bhav.


P.s. 

  • If you’d like to leave your name I’d like to thank you personally.  I hope to update this page (and social media eventually) with progress updates nearer June. 

How you can donate efficiently:

  • UK tax payers can tick the Gift Aid box to ensure that JustGiving recovers the tax you’ve already paid on your donation for Sightsavers.
  • Please also keep a record of your donation for your Self Assessment tax return where applicable.
  • Donations from companies may not recover Gift Aid, but may be a business expense.

A web link to Sightsavers home page is further down...

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
I will be undertaking a mammoth trek of 100km from London to Brighton in 24 hours. Some of you may remember I did this some years ago, but  completed the trek slower than my target time of 24 hours, due to awful weather and blisters the size of cocktail sausages. So a few years older, fatter and creakier, I have foolishly decided to have another go. 

Now my knees, back and ankles aren't so good, and I often make an "oof" noise when I get out of a low chair, but I am determined to finish in under 24 hours. I will be supporting Sightsavers, whose work fighting avoidable blindness and supporting people with disabilities I whole-heartedly believe in (I do work for them, after all).

So please give generously if you can, and take comfort in the fact that I haven't asked you to do this with me...

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I’m running the Conakry 12km again but this year to raise money for equipment for the SOGUE (meaning “sun”) blind school in Conakry.  The school was founded in 2002 and has 45 children - 15 girls and 30 boys.  The funds raised will buy learning tools such as braille paper, slates, letters, styluses and cubarithmes. With these we hope to contribute a little more light to the lives of visually impaired children in this developing country.  

As ever I thought hard about  running the half marathon, but Conakry’s 30+ degree heat and high humidity beats me every time and I’ve decided that 12km is still my limit. 

I’ll be contributing through Sightsavers UK who have agreed to collect your contributions and donate them specifically to the SOGUE school. In Guinea Sightsavers are working on Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) some of which are diseases of the  eyes such as River Blindness. I know the Sightsavers team here well and am certain that they will squeeze the maximum value for the school from even the smallest amounts of support.  

Sightsavers UK’s overall mission is to eliminate avoidable blindness and promote equality of opportunity for people with disabilities, and they work in over 30 countries.  In 2017 they hit a record 1 billion NTD treatments  across the world - a phenomenal milestone.

story:
I did it! The picture above is at mile 17 with just 9 miles to go. Blow by blow account in updates section below but it was not pretty with a hamstring injury and cramps and 80 minutes slower than my last attempt in 2014. But together we have raised over £7,400 (inclusive of gift aid) for Sightsavers which is truly amazing. Thank you so much. 

I turned 60 this February and wanted to celebrate this by running to support this great charity. This was my sixth London marathon since my wife and kids told me (with good justification) in my mid-40s that I was going to seed so I am indebted to them. 

As a general surgeon who has served in a Kenyan mission hospital I've witnessed first-hand the devastating damage that blindness can do to individuals and communities but also know how effective and cheap preventive and curative measures are. 

As CEO of Christian Medical Fellowship I'm deeply committed to healthcare in the developing world.

In five previous marathons between 2004 and 2014  friends and colleagues generously helped me to raise over £25,000 for Whizz Kidz, Alzheimer's Society, Down's Syndrome, Help the Hospices and Christian Blind Mission so this latest effort brings the grand total to over £30,000. 

If you still want to give it is not too late. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As many of you know I walked the 192 mile Coast to Coast path in September 2015 raising £2500 for Sightsavers.

I chose this charity as in 2015 I had laser eye surgery which meant I didn’t have to wear glasses anymore. I realised how lucky I was to have the choice and money to just make a decision and go to have the treatment unlike many others who have to live with their vision impairment.

When I read about A Million Miracles I felt the need to help as much as I could. Sightsavers work is very inspiring.

My Coast to Coast walk was an organised group that I joined with my friend Elizabeth. There were 14 of us in all and we soon became very good friends spending 14 days walking and chatting about anything and everything to while away the long hours across the Lake District, Yorkshire Dales and North York Moors. It was during these chats that 2 people, separate of each other suggested I take up running. I poo pooed them and said I had never even run across the road for a bus and there was no way I could go running but it stuck with me and I kept thinking about it.

When I got home I felt physically and mentally strong after walking 192 miles even though my feet felt like horse’s hooves.

I decided not to let the strength disappear and so I downloaded the app, Couch to 5K, and tentatively started the first 1 minute run that nearly killed me. Soon I was running a bit more every week and eventually I reached the 5K (30 minutes) and I cried. Not from pain but from the sense of achievement.

I quickly decided to down load the app 5k-10k and set off to double my distance over a period of months. Eventually cracking the 10K distance.

At this point I didn’t know if I should continue as I was worried I was too old and would destroy my knees. But my sensible head went out of the window as I downloaded the app 10K-21K and started to work towards the half marathon. I live in Ealing and there is a very good half marathon every year in September which goes right past the front of my house. I usually go out every year to clap the runners past, never dreaming that I would ever be able to do such a thing. (As of September 24th 2017 I have now completed that half marathon in 2 hours and 8 minutes and am very happy with that time for my first effort.)

I then received an email from Margaret (one of the ladies who was on the coast to Coast walk) to say that her friend Karen was going to be running in the London Marathon in April 2017 for charity and would we consider sponsoring her. Karen was very special to us, she was not just any old friend of Margaret, she went out of her way to drive across the UK with a box of homemade chocolate brownies and a bottle of fizz for us all on our last day. She met us in a small village about 2 hours walk from Robin Hood’s Bay (our final destination) with the brownies to share out amongst us to give us all a chocolate boost and then drove on to Robin Hood’s Bay with the fizz and shared it all out with a glass for each of us to celebrate our wonderful achievement as we dipped our toes in the water. What a wonderful friend.

Of course, I sponsored Karen, after all, one good turn deserves another even after one and a half years had gone by. I then spent all of Sunday morning trying to spot her on TV in the marathon. It was at this point that I decided I could do this. I could run that marathon too as I watched everyone running the course. So here I am with a place and am absolutely petrified, what have I done? But I WILL do this and hope to raise a good sum for Sightsavers and all those eyesights that will be restored to people who have lost hope.

I hated sports at school and was always useless. Sports day was my biggest nightmare as I ran around hurdles and under the high jump and would hide in the toilets. Who would think that in my 60th year I would attempt to do such a thing as run the London marathon? I wish my teachers could see me now.

Last year I ran in my first ever race, the Osterley 10K. it was 26 degrees that morning but I completed it in literally seconds over the hour and I was the proud owner of my first ever running medal. (I went to bed in it that night and woke up with the medal part under my armpit ) I have since hung it up to remind me of what i can achieve when I decide to do something. My Ealing Half marathon was run in 20 degrees and full sunshine but I completed it and now have a second medal which I also wore to bed that night!! I can feel a tradition starting here.

At the beginning of February I also completed, with a personal best of 57 minutes, the London Winter 10k run with 20,000 other people, starting in Trafalgar Square and running basically to St Paul's and back round the streets of London. It was freezing cold but so much fun and honestly, I felt like I would have liked to turn round and do it all again when I got to the end. I wanted to experience what it was like to run with so many people in London before the big MARATHON day.

I have now completed the hottest London marathon on record, 24.1 degrees officially, in a time I am really chuffed with, 4:59:17, a fraction under the 5 hour mark. It was challenging and hot but I was well trained (I had run 419 miles during the previous 5 months), well fuelled thanks to my lovely Craig and well hydrated due to no alcohol at all for at least a month before. I felt strong and determined and when it got tough around 23-24 miles I gave myself a good talking to and ran on to get over the line in just under the 5 hours which was my aim. 

I love my medal, its heavy and bears all the weight of the effort involved to obtain it. I will never forget that day for the rest of my life, I ran with a massive smile most of the way. Apologies in advance if you still see me wearing my medal now and again but I am chuffed to bits with it :)

I am now an official marathoner at the age of 59 and a half!!! xxx

I wrote a blog about my Coast to Coast walk if you want to read about my effort. How did I know that it would be the start of something much larger?

http://lozandherboots.blogspot.co.uk/

eventName: Alison goes alcohol free for January!
story:
Hi all I hope you all had a wonderful Christmas and New Year!

I have decided to give up alcohol for January in attempt to raise money for Sightsavers charity.

Did you know 75% of sight loss can be cured or prevented?! Imagine facing vision loss that could be cured or prevented.. but you are unable to get the help required due to your place of birth.

I was recently referred to hospital during an eyetest, without this intervention I may have risked losing my vision. I was sent to A&E by a lovely and very competent lady called Hannah at Vision Express Bury st Edmonds and was looked after very well by the NHS West Suffolk hospital where a diagnosis of viral meningitis was made. I am now home and I am under the care of the outpatient opthomology service. I was fortunate to get the help/care/treatment I needed, others born into poverty are not so lucky. Sightsavers can change lives of children and adults around the world, where there isn’t adequate healthcare services.

Sightsavers really do change lives. Every year, sightsavers support their partners to carry out millions of eye examinations and refer people for treatment to prevent blindness and restore sight.

Please donate generously if you can.. as you all know I am partial to a glass of wine, but it will be a pleasure to go without this month if it means I can raise some money for Sightsavers! 

If you can’t donate please take from this the importance of eye tests both routinely and if you notice any changes to vision or headaches etc.

Thanks for reading!!

Alison xxx

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Our brother, Geoff Pyke, died on Christmas Day after a short illness. Following a successful career as a chemical engineer, Geoff applied his considerable intellect to studying history and was finalising his PhD.  

Anne and Geoff loved to travel and visited many less developed countries where they saw the huge difference that organisations such as Sightsavers make to the quality of life. Relatively straightforward eye operations, such as the one Geoff had as a three year old, are beyond the means of so many families in developing countries. Sightsavers seeks to redress this balance.                                                                

Please join us in making donations in memory of Geoff to enable Sightsavers to continue this valuable work.

Thanks from Bill and Lin Pyke

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Shave Santa - get rid of that hairy bundle and be clean shaven - Lose the beard!


SightSavers - the reason ... for those that don't know, I am totally blind in my left eye after many attempts to save the sight following a Giant Retinal Tear that turned into a Retinal Detachment. The other eye, well, it has had an operation to save the sight and the fear of becoming completely blind (complete darkness with no light perception at all) lives with me every single day. I am lucky, I can still see, some people around the world do not and it is worst in developing countries that lack resources. It is for others that we live on this planet, to love others and care for them.

As a bit of fun and considering so many people see my chubby cheeks, my real life belly, my white hair, my love of wearing a red suit at Christmas and ... of course ... the white beard, I decided to try raising funds for charities:

- Shave Santa cause will raise funds for SightSavers International being a charity that helps prevent blindness, supports blind people and performs so many good functions in the developing world.

- Save Santa cause will raise funds for the Ardgowan Hospice.

The cause that raises the most amount of money will see me either Shave the Santa trade mark beard or Save the Santa trade mark beard. On the 22nd December this year, my face will either continue to look like Santa or it will be clean shaven!!!


This page is to raise funds for SightSavers International, to help prevent blindness and help people who are blind in developing countries around the world.

They need our help, love and support.


The beard has been with me for many years now and over the years has become very white. I have been quite attached to it!!!


As for the Save Santa cause ... from the start of my mum's illness, all the early symptoms and no-one knowing the reasons, through the diagnosis of Pancreatic Cancer, followed by the horrific last few weeks was one of the most upsetting times of our lives.

The Save Santa page will raise funds for the Ardgowan Hospice to care for so many more people nearing the end of their lives and support so many families. As for the Save Santa page, it will raise funds for the Ardgowan Hospice who provide care that words just don't do justice. The incredible care for my mum and the kindness shown to my whole family was something that we will always remember. The people at the Ardgowan Hospice are fantastic and the place itself is somewhere so many families turn to throughout the year every year. The support before, during and after is second to none.

So, you decide. Save or Shave Santa this year ... for a good cause. Vote by donating. The winner is not me not matter, it is two great charities and a bit of fun at the same time. It will be exciting to see what will happen. I personally just hope both charities receive some good amounts of money from people around the world; as for the beard, I wonder what I will look like come the New Year. All will be revealed and please share this page far and wide. I am willing to do whatever it takes to raise as much money as possible in memory of Mum - the bravest person I have ever loved xxx

story: As you know, Tom was a wonderful human being. He died of a heart attack whilst cycling in Kazakhstan in August this year.  In his memory, there will be a collection for the charity Sightsavers.  It is a charity he particularly favoured as his sight was so poor and he was always so careful of and dependent on his glasses.  Having been in Kenya for two years, he was keenly aware of how lucky we are in the UK to have the NHS to sort out eye problems and provide glasses for those that need them. Sightsavers is a UK-based international charity which fights avoidable blindness, and promotes equal opportunities for visually impaired people. It also supports surgeons in their cataract operations in the field in countries on many continents, including Africa.

story:
If you are looking at this page I have invited you to my 50th birthday party on June 16th. Instead of bringing me a present that I won't know what to do with on the night, I am asking everyone to give at least £5 to Sightsavers.  This is enough for them to restore sight to a child somewhere less fortunate than this. 

Just think about that for a moment.

If all 50 of you donate £5 to this page, 50 kids will see the sun catching a cobweb, or a rainbow, or their Mum's smile. That's quite a gift to give. 

I'd rather wake up to that thought on June 17th than a pile of presents.

You can always give more than £5 of course. 

And if you buy me a present as well, I'll forgive you :-)

THANK YOU 

Trainboy (and 50 kids who would stay blind otherwise)

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
I got my first (Lion King) glasses when I was 8 and with a prescription of -8.5 my specs have long been my safety net. I was fortunate to grow up with optional extras to make life easier; clip-on sunglasses (I was cool), prescription swimming goggles, then contact lenses and even some creative Dad-inventions (old lenses stuck inside a snorkelling mask). A few months ago I went one better and benefitted from the incredible technology of Laser Eye Surgery. Within 3 days I was deemed legal to drive without visual aid (pretty hard to comprehend when you've lived through -8.5).

Wearing glasses wasn't an issue (unsurprisingly I was used to it), but I always felt vulnerable to any situation in which they could be ripped away. In an emergency my confidence and independence would instantly be gone. And yet too many people don't even have the privilege of a simple pair of glasses or access to the everyday eye care that we can take for granted. I feel extremely fortunate to have grown up shortsighted in my world, yet others are unnecessarily losing their sight to treatable conditions or struggling with everyday activities.

As I celebrate my first spec-free birthday in over 20 years, I'm asking friends and family to donate towards my fundraising campaign to give others the gift of sight. Thank you!
title: A gift of sight
pageSummary: I am raising money because I'm celebrating a spec-free birthday

Name: A gift of sight

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Say goodbye to our amazing flowing hair. 

Three of us here at Traveleyes - a tour company helping the visually impaired see the world - are shaving our heads for Sightsavers who do fantastic work all over the world. 

There are 39 million blind people in the world, but 80 per cent of blindness can be cured or prevented. That’s 31.2 million people who are blind when they needn’t be.

Sightsavers want to eliminate avoidable blindness and support people who are irreversibly blind or disabled to live independently.

So please give generously through our just giving page and remember to add gift aid.

We will put up a video on Facebook and YouTube so please make sure you like and subscribe to watch the shaving happen.

https://www.facebook.com/traveleyesltd
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC6yFbJDy43RPNfgUxrF1rhg

Thank you so much for your support.

The Traveleyes Team.
title: Traveleyes' Goodbye to Luscious Locks

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Hellooo everyone! 

It's been a long time since I've been involved in any sort of fundraising events! Here I am, challenging myself to do a skydive (Yes I mean it!) to raise fund for sightsavers! 

Sightsavers is an international organisation that helps to combat blindness and provide support to people especially those who are less fortunate. Most importantly, sightsavers provide services to partially sighted or the blind to help them achieve a better quality of life they deserve. 

Sight and vision is important because it allows us to connect to the surroundings and to perceive beauty that nature has to offer. They also keep us safe.

Right now 39 million people in the world suffer from blindness - and 80% of them are potentially curable and preventable if they have the right resources.

Why not help make a difference? Help change the lives of people who are at risk of losing their sight.

Thank you!

When I reach the target - challenge accepted!

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I've been growing my hair for almost 2 years now but on the 12th May I will be getting it all shaved off - who knows what's under there?!

I chose to raise money for Sightsavers for a couple of reasons. Firstly, the cause is something close to my heart; although not blind by any stretch, without corrective surgery for my short sight I'd be unable to drive or even recognise people standing a few meters away. If I'd been born in a different part of the world I'd have really struggled with everyday life due to my poor vision.

Secondly, I'm really keen on giving effectively - basically getting as much 'bang for your buck' when donating to charities. Sightsavers score highly in this regard as 91% or all money donated goes straight to helping people with sight issues and much of the treatments are very cost effective.

Any and all donations are massively appreciated and will be going to an extremely worthwhile cause.

Will be sure to share some before and after pics with all sponsors!

Thanks,

Stef﻿

﻿﻿

eventName: Shaving my head for children with Trachoma.
story:
I will be shaving my head on May 18th 2017 in order to raise money for people suffering from Trachoma. Trachoma is a bacterial eye infection that makes the eyelids turn inwards until your eyelashes scrape against the surface of your eyes. Slowly, you go blind. However, this disease is easily preventable with antibiotics, but many cannot afford or access antibiotics. People affected with this are usually living in rural areas with no direct connection to a health centre and have no effective methods of transport. Even a small amount of money can buy a lot of antibiotics and treat a lot of people. 

Many thanks for considering giving to this cause.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
We, as a family would like to fundraise for Sightsavers in loving memory of Mariyah Jasrai. Mariyah was diagnosed with Ewing's Sarcoma, an extremely aggressive form of cancer at the age of 7 and a half and engaged in a battle with it up until the age of 16, where she endured a plethora of treatments including chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgery in both conventional and experimental variations. She was subjected to an overwhelming bombardment of hardship, pain and suffering throughout her years but despite that she continued to plough on with her strong character, will and determination. 

The tumour originated in her femur and then continued to grow and metastasise around her body but she continued to fight it at every step of its progression. She endured inhumane amounts of pain, sickness and suffering caused by combination of the disease and the side effects of the rudimentary treatments that exist today. These did not phase her up until December 2016 when she was experiencing severe headaches and blurry vision and we were told that the cancer had metastasised into her brain which is extremely rare for her form and that it was applying pressure to her eyes, thus distorting her vision. She underwent radiotherapy which was unsuccessful and we were not able to contain the tumour within her. It continued to colonise her brain and eventually it grew on her optic nerves and she effectively lost her vision. 

Mariyah had endured every side effect and possible manifestation of pain but it did not defeat her, however when she lost her eyesight, she was absolutely distraught. Her character had changed, her will wasted away and she began to lose herself and eventually so would we. For Mariyah, her vision was her connection to the outside world, even when she was cornered by the unstoppable forces of nature within her, it allowed her to see the comforting smile of her parents faces or even the photos that would evoke her favourite memories that would provide her with the hope and thus determination to fight; however when this connection was severed she was defeated as she entered the dark abyss of the end of her life. 

Sadly, she lost her battle on the 19th of April 2017. However, before she had passed she had heard about Sighsavers and their pledge to treat blind children and restore their vision by removing their cataracts. When she heard that it would only cost £4 per eye, she immediately wanted to contribute to restore the vision of as many children as she could as she was enraged that it could be done so easily. Even though she knew that her vision could not be restored, she wanted to impact the lives of those that could be treated as she had endured their pain. She wanted to add this extremely personal pledge to her portfolio of charitable work but unfortunately she was not able to do so. Therefore, we would like to carry out Mariyah's wish to pledge and continue her profound impact on this planet by giving the gift of sight.
title: Fundraising in loving memory of Mariyah Jasrai
pageSummary: I am fundraising because I would like to restore the eyesight of 2500 kids.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit Phoebe Woollcombe's JustGiving page.

Phoebe, who died suddenly of cancer in November, was always the most charitable of souls. She gave to dozens of charities, worked in a charity shop for years, and organized the Red Cross charity flag sellers in her parish for 30 years, all unpaid and out of the goodness of her large heart. 

But Sightsavers was especially close to that heart, the one cause above all others that she wanted to support. For her, blindness was the most terrible of afflictions, and Sightsavers' mission to eliminate avoidable blindness and to make the world a fairer place for people with such disabilities was something that deserved the widest possible support.

And while she loved flowers, she always thought it wrong that money would be lavished on flowers for a funeral (which wouldn't benefit the deceased), when it could be spent to much better effect and benefit far more by being given to a good cause such as Sightsavers.

Phoebe was not a great one for computers, always preferring handwritten letters, phone calls and face-to-face contact, but she diligently attended a computer class for years, learning (just about) how to read and write emails. She was a great pragmatist, however, and she did accept that, even if it was all gobbledygook to her, the internet could be harnessed for good purposes. Hence this page – and the comparable one for her late, much missed husband Dick (https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/richardwoollcombe) in aid of the Alzheimer's Society – had her blessing, in the hopes that it would help her precious cause of Sightsavers. 

So, whether you knew Phoebe and want to give something in her memory, or whether you think Sightsavers is an admirable cause and deserves support, thank you for whatever you can give.

PS  Why is this page called Phoebe's Online Egg Round? Simple: as anyone who lived near her will know, once a week she would go round the local village selling eggs from her hens to friends and neighbours. She always called this her egg round, and it became very much a social event, with her driving home full to the gills after 15 cups of tea and endless chat. She also milked it for all she was worth when she was selling flags for the Red Cross. This page is very much in the same shameless spirit, hence the name!

Finally, here's the official blurb:

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Have you survived the Black Friday frenzy? Now it’s #GivingTuesday, you can help a Syrian child survive.

3.5 million Syrian children will be forced to face another freezing winter sleeping in a tent, without adequate clothing or protection from the cold. They don't have the protection to withstand the freezing winter. Your donation can help us keep children warm.

A donation of £3 from you could provide a blanket to keep a child safe from the cold.

Please donate on #GivingTuesday and join us on this national day dedicated to giving back. Together we can protect Syrian children from the deadly winter.

If you donate today, the UK government will match your fundraising pound for pound.
title: Unicef's #GivingTuesday for the children of Syria

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Please donate today to help children in Vanuatu affected by Cyclone Pam

When an emergency happens, it's a race against the clock to reach the children who need our help. Sadly in conflicts and emergencies like cyclones, it's children who are amongst the most vulnerable, so it's important we get there fast.

Unicef is on the ground in Vanuatu and the region providing shelter, clean drinking water, psychological support and medical help. 

Your donation today could help us give life-saving support to a child affected by Cyclone Pam, and provide support in their community during the aftermath.

Please donate today and help us protect children in danger after Cyclone Pam.

Funds raised for this appeal will support children affected by the Tropical Cyclone Pam in the South Pacific. If the funds raised exceed Unicef's funding requirements for this appeal, the money will go to Unicef UK's Children's Emergency Fund.
title: Donate to Unicef's Vanuatu Cylone Pam Appeal

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Right now, children are in danger from Ebola and they need our help.

The money you donate to our Ebola crisis appeal tonight will help provide vital protection for children affected by the outbreak, and stop the virus spreading.

Every pound you donate to help Unicef beat Ebola will be doubled by the UK Government until Monday 24 November 2014.

We've already delivered hundreds of tonnes of life-saving supplies, including hospital beds, life-saving food and protection kits for families and health workers.

But we’re in a race against time to contain the outbreak, and we urgently need more donations to help keep children safe.

Just £30 could buy and deliver a protection kit to keep a family safe from Ebola.

Please donate online to help protect a child from Ebola

WHAT YOUR DONATION COULD BUY

£5 will help provide supplies like gloves, masks, soap and chlorine to protect children from this deadly virus

£30 could buy and deliver a protection kit to keep a family safe from Ebola.

£50 could provide over 20 buckets, which can be used in health centres to prevent infection.

£75 could provide a tarpaulin to be used as a temporary community shelter for children and families affected by the outbreak.
title: FOOTBALLING RIVALS UNITE TO BEAT EBOLA

story:
I am going to challenge myself to the Water Walk as my first campaign with Unicef UK.

I will be walking 5 miles - or 8km - every day for one week (17th - 21st) this September to support children who have to walk at least that distance every day to collect water.

I have decided to make it harder by carrying 10kg while I walk. I am doing this to show solidarity with children who walk to collect water while carrying up to 20 litres with them. 

Join me by donating what you can and, together, we can contribute to the 2030 goal of no one having to walk for more than 30 minutes round trip for water.

Thank you!

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: Help raise money for UNICEF UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

UNICEF on Campus is a student initiative supporting the work of UNICEF (United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund) through both fundraising activities and awareness-raising events here at the University and in the wider Hull community. UNICEF works to provide both emergency aid and long-term development projects to some of the world's most vulnerable children.

UNICEF helps children receive the support, healthcare and education they need to survive the threats of childhood poverty - such as preventable diseases or malnutrition - and grow up to become healthy adults. 

Please help us by donating through our JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Right now, 6.5 million Syrian children need immediate humanitarian aid. Many have been forced to flee the country, losing their homes, their families, even their lives.  By holding our Sing for Syria fundraiser, we can help protect Syrian children in danger.

Plus, every donation you make to help Syrian children in danger will be matched pound for pound by the UK Government until 30 January 2015.

On the 11th of December, we will be holding a Christmas caroling event outside the Student Union. We will be holding bucket collections on the day as well. Please come along and support us!

We have also set up this JustGiving page for you to make a donation online!   Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Diminish Death, Replenish Life

More than 800 children die every year because they don't have access to safe water and clean toilers. A staggering 16,000 children under the age of five die from diseases that are easy to prevent. 

Water and sanitation-related diseases such as diarrhoea are one of the biggest causes of death for children under five around the world. Poor sanitation, water and hygiene affect more than just children's health. Children - particularly girls - often miss out on education because schools lack proper toilets and hand-washing facilities. Others miss out because they have to spend their days making long journeys to collect clean water rather than going to school. Deadly diseases like measles, polio, tetanus, tuberculosis and diphtheria are all easily and cheaply preventable by vaccination. Yet children still die because they simply don't get the healthcare and life-saving vaccines they need. 

UNICEF provides vaccines to immunise almost half the world's children against preventable diseases. They also have water, sanitation and hygiene teams working in more than 100 countries, keeping children safe by providing better water supplies and sanitation facilities in schools and communities. However there is still so much more that can be done to help, which is why we at Surrey UNICEF on Campus have decided to focus on this issue for the upcoming semester. We hope we can count on your support to make a difference!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
**UPCOMING CHALLENGE** Yorkshire 3 Peaks

September 2018: This September 110 CPD legends will be climbing, walking or maybe even running the Yorkshire 3 Peaks. This is nearly the distance of a full marathon around the Yorkshire Dales, with bad weather (likely) and on only very little sleep (definitely)!

**COMPLETED CHALLENGE**

October 2018: 35 Team Garnier & CPD heroes will be pounding again the streets in the Royal Parks Half Marathon, London. More info to come! 

8th October 2017: 32 Team Garnier legends will be pounding the streets in the Royal Parks Half Marathon, London. Please come along to cheer us along on the day, race starts at 9am!

6-8th September 2017: the #TourdeGarnier team take on 3 days, 210 miles and hill after hill on their bikes from Manchester to London.

﻿Thank you very much for supporting the Garnier + Unicef partnership to raise money to help children in emergency situations. 

Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. Today, children in places like Syria, South Sudan and Yemen are caught up in violent conflict, with millions forced to flee their homes. In 2015, Unicef responded to 310 emergencies in 102 countries. 

Please donate what ever you can to support Unicef UK. With your help, we can build a safer world for children.

story: This is Warwick UNICEF On Campus's first campaign of the year. This time, we want to raise awareness about and bring our support to the thousands of (often unaccompanied) refugee children on the roads in Europe and in refugee camps. Europe is facing a border and refugee crisis with an unprecedented scale and our reaction is often to shield ourselves, closing our borders and our hearts. Our goal is to make people more aware about the implications of the reactions of European countries and to offer financial support to UNICEF UK for the work it is doing for the Syrian crisis and the refugee crisis.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Following the Ebola epidemic, Liberia faces a severe crisis of malnutrition in its young kids today. 10,000 children die every year as they are undernourished and almost a third of young Liberian children are stunted, which can be deadly in a child's first 1000 days of his life. 

The situation will only worsen in the absence of proper nutrition commodities and access to treatment services. UNICEF and partners working hard to ensure delivery of essential micronutrients and helping more than 8,000 mothers save lives.

On November 19th, Warwick UNICEF on Campus will be undertaking a 24 hour sponsored fast to raise money for UNICEF's appeal for Liberia's malnutrition crisis.

Every small donation counts!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
UNICEF On Campus UK - UCL
Reference Number: 1025066621

UCLU UNICEF On Campus is appealing for the lives of the less fortunate children in Yemen and Syria. In Syria, more than 8 Million children are in danger, as they are threatened by the ongoing crises, depriving them of clean water and food. Many children were forced to become refugee as they flee from Syria with just their clothes on their backs, living in makeshift shelters, with inadequate protection from cold nights. In Yemen, the raging political unrests had left children in need of medical supplies, water, food, and shelter. Currently, 1.8 Million children are at risk of becoming malnourished.
In light of this, we are organizing a charity concert at UCL.

When: 11th March 2016, 19:00 - 21:00
Where: University College London, Garden Marquee
Tickets: https://uclu.org/whats-on/clubs-societies/unicef-society-gift-of-songs-charity-concert

We believe that the funds raised from tickets and merchandises will be a great ‘gift’ for the children in need, whether in providing warm clothes or food.

This page is dedicated to friends and families who want to help, but cannot make it to the concert. This is such that they will be able to donate any amount they want to contribute. All profit will goes towards UNICEF UK.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Syria continues to be one of the most dangerous places on Earth to be a child. Over 14 million Syrian children have been affected by the conflict, which is now in its fifth year. Unicef is one of the few organisations working inside Syria, as well as delivering humanitarian aid across the region.Our teams are working around the clock to provide life-saving food, clean water, health care and psychological support to children whose lives have been devastated by the conflict.

Help Unicef raise even more to support children affected by the conflict in Syria this winter by maximising your fundraising during the period 29 October 2015 and 30 January 2016.

The UK government will match fund pound for pound all fundraising made to the Syria Winter appeal between these dates enabling Unicef to do so much more through your fundraising.

Thank you for supporting our work with the children of Syria.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
For every child alone, for every child without a home


When European borders closed suddenly last year, it left thousands of refugee children stuck. Children are fleeing war and disaster in greater numbers than ever before, and tens of thousands of these children make the journey alone. Even those who travel with family often end up separated and stranded at transit centres. With governments not providing safe and legal routes for families fleeing war and conflict, children have been left with no options other than to rely on smugglers who will often take advantage of their desperate situation. They can be exploited and used for child labour, which often includes sexual exploitation. 

In order to help refugee children on these journeys UNICEF have established child and family support hubs - known as Blue Dot centres because of their distinctive blue dot marking - across Europe to provide help and support to children and families. We at Surrey UNICEF are embarking on a new campaign this semester to aid these efforts, raising both awareness and funding for this issue. Please show us your support and donate!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

From 7pm on Sunday 22 November until 7pm on Monday 23 November, members of UNICEF On Campus Aberystwyth are taking part in Fast 24 – a 24 hour sponsored fast – to raise money for and awareness about UNICEF. And we would really appreciate your sponsorship!

UNICEF do incredible work in over 190 countries to protect and promote children’s rights and every donation, big or small, helps towards this work. One of the key things we want to highlight with this event is the situation in Liberia, where UNICEF are working to combat malnutrition. Almost half of children in Liberia are malnourished and the Ebola crisis has only put a strain on Liberia’s infrastructure, making ensuring nourishment for Liberian children even more crucial. A donation of £5 can provide a severely malnourished child with food for 6 days.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Could you go 24 hours without food and be expected to live a normal healthy life?

This is the challenge faced daily for approximately 11.3% of the world's population including children. Every minute, more than five child mortalities can be attributed to malnutrition. For those fortunate to survive, malnutrition has detrimental effects on childhood growth and learning abilities.

Through FAST 24, Lancaster University students will go without food on 25th November to raise money for UNICEF's emergency food programmes.

The United Nation's International Children's Emergency UNICEF is a charity part of the United Nation's Development Group committed to protection of children worldwide. UNICEF provides 80% of the world's life-saving food through its nutrition programmes. 

With your help, we can help increase access to good nutrition to children worldwide giving them a healthier, happier life.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Nearly 10 million children are in danger in Yemen. Please donate now and help keep a child safe.

Yemen is facing a major humanitarian crisis. Four years of unrest has left children in urgent need of food, water and medical supplies. Now, the situation is worsened by fierce fighting and heavy air strikes.

1.8 million children are currently at risk of becoming malnourished. Due to food shortages across the country, nutrition supplies are rapidly depleting and need to be replenished in most health facilities. Unicef and partners have worked hard to ensure that almost 1,250 tonnes of life-saving supplies have been delivered to Yemen since March. But we need your help to reach more children in danger.

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: UNICEF ON CAMPUS CYCLONE PAM: URGENT APPEAL
story:
IMPACT 

It is estimated that 132,000 people, around half the population have been affected, of which 60,000 are children. As most houses are built with natural and local material, the extent of the damage of homes is believed to be devastating. Up to 90% buildings in the capital Port Vila were affected. 36 schools are being used as evacuation centres by over 2,000 evacuees. Communications are down and the airport is currently inoperable except for military planes. Tuvalu, Solomon Islands and Kiribati have also been severely affected by the cyclone. A state of emergency was declared in Tuvalu, Kiribati saw tidal waves as high as 4 meters and a second cyclone, Nathan, is meant to reach Solomon Islands next week. Assessments are planned to measure the damage in these island nations. 

What UNICEF is doing to help?

1. Water and Sanitation – UNICEF is the lead agency coordinating all activities under the Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) cluster group. It will provide drinking water and sanitation, including evacuation centres in schools and churches.

2. Health and Nutrition – Support emergency health services including distribution of essential drugs and vaccines as well as the deployment of health workers and nurses to affected provinces. A measles vaccination plan is being put together.

3. Education – Establishment of temporary learning spaces and distribution of basic school supplies.

4. Child protection – Provide psychological support for children and provide care for children separated and orphaned.

5. Supplies – Limited contingency stocks in the island will be immediately distributed. While supplies from the global warehouse are sent, other life-saving items will be shipped from Fiji. The delivery of supplies and services to remote islands is challenging in terms of logistics, delivery and distribution costs.

P R I C E P O I N T S 

£11 could enable a family to collect and store clean water with an emergency water kit

 £21 could provide blankets for five babies £55 could protect 500 children from polio by providing life-saving vaccinations

 £135 could make sure 40 children can continue their education with Unicef’s school in a box

 £990 could supply a tent for a temporary school or heath centre

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
After three years of conflict, more Syrian children than ever before need our help. Millions of children in Syria and the surrounding region are in danger. They face losing their homes, their families and even their lives. Torn from everything they know, they're left vulnerable to many other dangers, from disease and malnutrition to violence and exploitation. 

Right now, 6.5 million Syrian children need immediate humanitarian aid. Children shouldn't be the victims of war. Togther, we can keep them safe. By donating today, you can help UNICEF protect Syrian children in danger. 

For 250 days, our members will do a wide range of activities to raise charity for this fund, from skydiving to marathons, 24-hour fast to trekking. Please support us.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

 UNICEF On Campus Aberystwyth are part of UNICEF On Campus Wales, and we work with other UK universities to raise funds and awareness for UNICEF- the world's leading children's charity. UNICEF work in over 190 countries worldwide to ensure that the world's children are fed, vaccinated, educated and protected.

 On Sunday 23rd November, members of UNICEF On Campus Aberystwyth will be taking part in Mission 24- a 24 hour fast, starting at 8pm on Sunday and finishing at 8pm the following Monday, in order to raise funds for UNICEF. And we would really appreciate your sponsorship! UNICEF do incredible work worldwide, and every donation, big or small, helps towards this. A donation of £5 can provide a severely malnourished child with food for 6 days!

 Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
20th November is Universal Children's Day. Warwick UNICEF on Campus thought this would be the perfect opportunity to raise awareness for UNICEF as a children's charity.

By looking back at our favourite childhood memories, we realise that not all children are so lucky. If you believe a child deserves to grow up in a safe, happy environment, please join us in changing your Facebook profile picture to a favourite childhood memory. Don't forget to text "UNIC53 £3" to 70070, add #minime and nominate three other friends to do the same! 

Let's try and only have childhood profile pictures across Facebook by 20th November.

Thank you!


Special thanks must go to fellow UNICEF on Campus societies (Birmingham, Imperial College, Queen Mary, Sheffield, Swansea and UCLU), Warwick LINE Society and Warwick Economics Society for joining us in this campaign.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
On 14-15th November, Warwick UNICEF on Campus will partake in our annual 24 hour sponsored fast "Mission24" to raise money for UNICEF’s Ebola Crisis Appeal. 

The current crisis West Africa is the largest Ebola outbreak ever reported, with an estimated 8.5 million children and youth under 20 years old living in Ebola-affected areas. Of them, 2.5 million are under the age of five. UNICEF estimates that 3,700 chilren have been orphaned by Ebola.

We can stop Ebola. UNICEF is airlifting essential supplies, distributing vital health information and caring for children and families. With early treatment, they can survive this disease.

However, due to a lack of funds, UNICEF has found it difficult to reach every child and community in danger. 

So please donate whatever you can to this fantastic cause - it will make a real difference!

Feel free to have a look at our team page to see how we're doing.

Thank you!

story:
264 million children (!!!) around the world don't have the opportunity to enter or complete school. They are prevented from doing so by things way beyond their own control: poverty, armed conflict, climate change, discrimination..

I've had a hugely privileged education and upbringing, so I hope this small act will help raise a bit of money to give other children around the world even a slice of the opportunities I have had...(£30 = exercise books and pens for over 70 kids)

I know this is a bit cheesy and that every man and his dog is running a half marathon but... any small donation makes a huge difference!

Thank you! 

Olive xxx

story:
Hello and thanks for visiting! My name's Cressida and I'm a student midwife based in Manchester.  I've started this JustGiving page as a booster to fund-raise for my chosen charity, UNICEF. As well as hosting a CookForSyria dinner party in Autumn, I'm organising weekly bake sales to complement this. To read more about how the funds are used or how you can help, please visit UNICEF's official page.

"We hope that through the #CookForSYRIA campaign we will not only be able to raise much needed money for Unicef’s Children of Syria Fund, we will also increase awareness of the plight of children in the war-torn country. Through cooking, sharing recipes and the power of social media, we invite everyone to help make a difference and positive contribution towards this important initiative" - Clerkenwell Boy

Winning Observer Food Monthly’s Best Ethical Food Project 2017, #CookForSyria is a nationwide fundraising initiative curated by Clerkenwell Boy SUITCASE Magazine and Gemma Bell, in partnership with Unicef NEXT Generation London, and in aid of Unicef UK. Recently inspired by this initiative, UNICEF NEXT Generation London, Lilly Vanilli, Clerkenwell Boy, Serena Guen and Gemma Bell also created #BakeForSyria.

You can buy the cookbooks here :

https://www.amazon.co.uk/Bake-Syria-Recipe-Book/dp/1527221962

https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/aw/d/1527203344/ref=pd_aw_fbt_14_img_2/257-1533745-6992906?ie=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=S16PMS8F96EZ3JF48EV8
