charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Fast24. Sounds easy? Think again. This is serious fasting for no less than 24 hours. One day and one night. 
Although this is seen as an extremely difficult challenge in our society, millions of people across the world are faced with starvation everyday. 
Imagine the uncertainty of not knowing whether you were going to be able to eat today, no matter how hungry you feel?
A group of us at Birmingham University have decided to take on the challenge to raise awareness for the current food crisis in West Africa and Liberia. We will fasting on Monday March 20th.
Every 12 SECONDS a child dies due to malnutrition. We are now into 2017, the new sustainable development goals have been formed, the world is becoming more globalised and yet certain parts of the world are being left behind. It's easy to think of countries in general; a low HDI value, poor levels of sanitation and high levels of malnutrition. However these facts are representing people. They are people in the 21st century who are still living in poverty, but we have the ability to help change this. Every donation big or small will make a huge difference. UNICEF supply's 80 percent of the worlds emergency food, it's not just a bundle of aid being given to a government. This money will be spent directly on the people who need it and they do. So please help us and donate to making a difference together.

story:
I know my friends and family would like to do something to help reduce the suffering in the world. You all know how much I love to eat the wonderful food that is so readily available in our part of the world.  So, I'm willing to fast in support of this cause.  Will you support my small effort?  My original target was £5 per hour...in less than 12 hours 5 folks with online donations and promises I have exceeded that, so I'm boldly going for £600 (£50 per hour) and have revised my target on this page  ! Thanks to all you lovely supporters of this cause.

This charity does a huge amount to support children in danger by providing education, life-saving food, clean water, vaccines, relief in emergencies and protection from violence - in over 190 different countries across the planet.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

After the marvelous experience of last year, I am going to run the Royal Parks Half Marathon 2018 raising money for UNICEF.

UNICEF works in 190 countries in the world to save children's lives, to defend their rights, and to help them from early childhood through adolescence.

They receive no funding from the UN budget. They rely entirely on voluntary donations like yours to fund their vital work to protect children in danger and building a safer world for tomorrow’s children.

Please give what you can. Every pound will make a difference to vulnerable children around the world.  

Once you donate, JustGiving.com will send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

"Children are the living messages we send to a time we will not see." - J. F. Kennedy

Thank you for your donation.

Today, children in places like Syria, South Sudan and Yemen are caught up in violent conflict, with millions forced to flee their homes. In 2015, Unicef responded to 310 emergencies in 102 countries. Please donate what ever you can to my fundraiser for Unicef UK. With your help, we can build a safer world for children.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease,  hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anything else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk 

Unicef UK

----------

The greatest part of being a Tom Hiddleston fan is that we have the most generous fan group in the world! Tom's fans have raised over £100,000 for various causes close to both his heart and theirs. Tom has been a passionate supporter of many causes over the course of his career. Most notably, he began serving as a Unicef UK Ambassador in 2013, with his first mission to Guinea. Tom's current focus with Unicef UK has been his work in South Sudan.

----------

Tom’s Midgardian Army is excited to announce their Unicef UK fundraiser. This fundraiser will support Unicef UK's work with children in crises all around the world. This fundraiser will coincide with Tom Hiddleston's appearance at ACE Comic Con in Chicago, as well as the Royal Parks Marathon on October 14, 2018. You can read more on Unicef UK's marathon team here. 

Anyone who donates to the fundraiser will be eligible to enter the #ACERaffle and win amazing prizes. Prize winners will be selected every other Monday beginning August 6-October 15.

Additionally, Tom’s Midgardian Army will be creating a book of messages/art to give Tom at ACE. You can either leave the message you wish to have included with your donation, contact the group, or email hiddlesfashion@gmail.com to be included. These messages need to be received by September 24th to ensure enough time for the book to be printed. All submissions will be reviewed first to make sure that they are appropriate. 

How to Enter the #ACERaffle:

  • Donate to the Unicef UK fundraiser
  • Leave the hashtag #ACERaffle in your donation message along with your email or screenname (twitter, tumblr, instagram etc) so that we can contact the winners.
  • You will receive ONE raffle entry for every £2 donated. (£2 is the minimum donation amount allowed by justgiving). 
    • ie: £2 = 1 entry, £4 = 2 entries, £6 = 3 entries

The Prizes:  

  • August 6th: The winner will receive a Loki Lego set and Marvel Loki lanyard - won by silentmaggie (donated by KTHunter_Author)
  • August 20th: The winner will receive the official I Saw the Light Soundtrack - won by say-my-name-assbut (donated by @MintMintDoodles)
  • September 3rd: The winner will receive a Tom Hiddleston Colour Me Good Book and M2 magazine  -won by swingcat25 (donated by amazingeddieredmayne)
  • September 17th: The winner will receive a Coriolanus Art Pop Tote -won by liebertwh (donated by @twh-news)
  • September 18th: To celebrate the 10th anniversary of Unrelated's release the winner will receive an Unrelated poster signed by Joanna Hogg, Kathryn Worth, and Mary Roscoe at the Stolen Summers Film Session. Thank you to the organizers for allowing us to get the poster and also to Helen for attending the event. - won by lisa_hiddles 
  • October 1st: We will have a double drawing! One winner will receive a Loki package that includes a Loki tote, Thor/Loki plush keychains, a Thor: Ragnarok movie magazine, Loki bookmark, and Infinity War figures (donated by HiddlesEducates).  A second winner will receive a 10 Anniversary Gold Loki Funko. 
  • October 15th: Our final prize winner will received a signed copy of #RADAHamlet. It’s inscribed with the words The rest is silence - which are Hamlet’s last words and was chosen to signify how Unicef UK is not silent to the plight of children around the world. 

There may be additional raffle prizes as the fundraiser reaches certain goals.

Janvanfirst and shannon3n88 each won a Loki Pez to celebrate our fundraiser reaching £7,000 and £28,000 total.  

Thank you to everyone for helping to support Unicef UK, our Past Charity Raffles have raised £26,897.17!


*These fundraisers/raffles are 100% fan driven  and not sponsored by any organization or individual.*

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
On September 16th every year, barbers all around the world unite to give back to a worldwide charity. All the money raised for the World Barber Day initiative is donated to a trusted Worldwide Charity. A World Barber Day Package is sent out to each barbershop worldwide who wishes to take part.

As we all know in the middle ages barbers were not only cutting hair and shaving, but also pulling teeth, dressing wounds and performing operations. these Barber – Surgeons actually formed their first organisation in France in 1096. In 1096 barbers were recognized for more than just men's hairstyles & shaves.

World Barber Day is an exhibition of how ordinary barbers are so much more than a barber – and how each barber can make a significant difference to the world in just one single day

We used the combination of 1096 (16/09) to signify the day barbers can revert back to Barber – Surgeons & make a worldwide difference.

Red and white striped with a hint of blue – a barber pole twisting next to a storefront signifies a place where men can get a haircut.On World Barber Day this signifies so much more.

 All Proceeds taken on the day will be donated directly to UNICEF.

– A Worldwide Charity. UNICEF fights for the rights of every child, everyday, across the globe.

story:
Shaving my head is something that I can do so easily and something that I don't consider a great sacrifice, so why wouldn't I do it there is the possibility of saving a child's life, or improving their quality of life. This wasn't a hard decision for me, in fact I don't know why I haven't done it sooner! IT'S JUST HAIR.

I think the work that UNICEF are doing around the world (especially right now) is extremely crucial and if I can offer my support in any way, I want to take that opportunity. I can't afford to give a big donation myself, so I would like to encourage you to donate whatever you can spare and LET'S DO GOOD THINGS TOGETHER.

p.s. Video to follow.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thank you for taking the time to read more. 

I am both excited and terrified to be celebrating a new decade by running the London Marathon this year. It will be my first marathon (challenge of any sort!) in more than a decade - since having my three wonderful children and time no longer being my own!

I am proud to be running for Unicef - an amazing charity that I have supported for many years. 

As a devoted mother I am deeply saddened by global inequality and that children worldwide still face hunger and lack of clean water, and die of easily preventable disease. 

Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, clean water, vaccinations, disaster relief, education and protection than any other organisation, and I passionately believe that the £'s my tired legs will raise will have a huge impact, both in the UK and worldwide. 

£5 can provide life-saving food for a severely malnourished child for a week

£14.50 can vaccinate and protect 100 children against polio

£25 could buy enough water purification tablets to provide more than 600 children with clean water for a whole month

Every few £’s makes a big difference, so please encourage me to keep running and help Unicef to build a safer, healthier future for all children. 

Very big thank you! 

Sarah x

PS. Donating through JustGiving is easy, fast and totally secure. Your money will be sent directly to Unicef, and your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails.

This time I am also running to raise funds for UNICEF, a charity that works to keep children safe worldwide. It's just not fair that some children have tougher lives simply because they have been born in the middle of a conflict or in a poor region of the world. Your donation will help UNICEF to provide more children with life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection. 

Thanks!

Oscar

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Since December of 2013, the civil war between two opposing forces in South Sudan, the government and its opposition, has been staggeringly detrimental to the lives of 3.4 million children who are directly affected. From then, more than 1 million children has been driven from homes, schools, and communities. Vulnerable to violence, exploitation, malnutrition, and diseases, their lives are faced with looming danger. At least 400,000 children have been school-less, 13,000 have been exploited by armed groups, let alone violence and sexual abuse.

As a charity society, we are raising funds and awareness in support of UNICEF UK in its effort to alleviate the conditions of children in South Sudan. FAST24 is an event in which around 100 participants fast for 24 hours to appeal for the lives of 77,000 children who are currently facing severe malnutrition. UNICEF On Campus UCL will be organizing a range of events including games, competitions, entertainments, as well as, educational documentary, and talks from external speakers who had first-hand experiences in helping less fortunate children in conflicted areas. All profit from this event will go towards UNICEF UK.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. Please help me raise as much money as possible. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity. 

The Clipper Round the World Yacht Race is one of the biggest challenges of the natural world and an endurance test like no other. At 40,000 nautical miles long, it is the biggest ocean race on the planet and the only event of its kind that exists for non-professional sailors. The race is one of Mother Nature’s toughest, the ultimate challenge which crosses six continents and will last almost twelve months.

Twelve teams compete against each other and I am lucky to be part of Team Unicef. I am taking part in 3 Legs of the race, sailing Leg 4 from Freemantle, Western Australia to Queensland, Eastern Australia for 6 weeks over Christmas and New Year 2017. Then I'm re-joining the boat in April 2018 for Leg 7 starting in Seattle, NW USA sailing through the Panama Canal, up to New York, USA, and finally Leg 8 across the Atlantic Ocean to Londonderry, N Ireland and arriving back into Liverpool in July 2018.

You can follow me and the race by logging into https://www.clipperroundtheworld.com

I know this is a huge challenge for me having never sailed before (and getting horribly seasick during my training weeks!) but knowing that I am raising money for Unicef worldwide will make the cold Atlantic crossing slightly more bearable when the waves are crashing over the bow!

Thank you for your support

Jen

story:
Would you like to write an inspiring message for the Clipper Race crew?

As the official Charity Partner of the Clipper 2017-18 Race, the heavyweight (Code 3) spinnaker on Unicef will have space on it for crew and supporters to write positive messages for Clipper Race crew that will be racing on board any yacht in the fleet. Your comment can play an important motivational role as the Clipper Race fleet sail over 40,000 nautical miles during their circumnavigation of the world.

Supporters were able to write a message, in return for a donation, on the Unicef spinnaker, in person, while the Clipper Race fleet were in Liverpool ahead of Race Start - this initiative raised around £1,000 in online and offline donations.

If you were unable to be In Liverpool, you can still be involved! All you need to do is provide a suggested minimum donation of £5 on this JustGiving page along with the message that you would like written on the spinnaker. Each of the yachts have a fundraising target of £30,000 so if you would like your donation to contribute to a particular team's total, please include that in the message (in brackets). Our team will then write your message on the spinnaker for you and a photo of all the messages will be uploaded on the Clipper Race Facebook page. Any messages that are received while the fleet are at sea will be written on the spinnaker at the next stopover.

(To allow as many messages as possible to be included on the spinnaker, please note that your message will not fill a space any larger than an A4 size page).

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My name is Maddie Booth and I'm a sixth form student at Wisbech Grammar school. On the 4th of March 2016, I am holding a Fashion Show, having organised it myself, at my school in order to raise money for the charity UNICEF. The 9 month process, which I have undergone, has included organising models, suppliers, decorations, entertainment and special guests from the community. Although it has taken up a lot of time, I am looking forward to the outcome of the night. 

The night will run from 7pm to 9pm. It will include a raffle great prizes such as a signed football from the Manchester United Team, food and drink, and a live band, choir and dance act and of course the cat walk show. I have clothing from Wisbech Grammar, and local schools fashion and textiles departments, and the local designer, Robert Goddards and other high street brands.

charity.name: Médecins Sans Frontières (UK)
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Dr Johan von Schreeb arrived in Guiuan in the east of Samar island yesterday, an area devastated by Typhoon Haiyan and where Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) emergency team is setting up its medical services and treating patients. They are creating what will be an integrated provision of mobile clinics, reaching out to the more isolated parts of the coast and islands, and outpatient services in the town of Guiuan itself. Guiuan had almost all of its buildings destroyed and the local hospital is not functioning. MSF will be providing water and sanitation services as soon as possible and will also assist with shelter.  

Building a temporary hospital is a priority as only minor surgery can be provided at present. Meanwhile the queues are growing, as tetanus jabs have to be administered to prevent the further infection and to help patients suffering with pneumonia and diarrhoea.

Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is the world's leading emergency medical humanitarian aid organisation.

We provide emergency assistance to people affected by armed conflict, epidemics and natural or man-made disasters, without discrimination and irrespective of race, religion, gender or political affiliation. 

We work in over 60 countries and go to the places where others cannot or choose not to go.

story:
We're committed to making a difference to our world, whether it's in our local area, in the UK, or globally. And this Christmas, we're donating £5000 to the ten listed charities at https://www.euro-point.co.uk/make-a-difference/ and we want you to be involved!

Every vote cast for a particular charity will mean that they are one step closer to gaining a proportion of the £5000 we are donating.

And once you have cast your vote, why not donate yourself to a charity of your choice, such as Médecins Sans Frontières , or maybe all of them.

Go on, give a little something for Christmas!

charity.name: Médecins Sans Frontières (UK)
story:
I’m fundraising for Medecins Sans Frontieres - Doctors Without
Borders (MSF), an international charity that delivers lifesaving medical care to the people who need it most - regardless of where they are - or whether their stories have hit the headlines.

If you haven’t heard of them, here’s a cool link about their
incredible work - https://www.msf.org.uk/msf-videos.

More than 90 percent of their funding comes from people like
you and me. This is important because it means they don’t need to take money from governments, which allows them to remain independent, act quickly and go where the need is greatest.

For example, it meant that MSF was the first organisation to
respond to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa and swiftly scaled up operations when the disease spread. It meant they could respond within hours to the devastating typhoon in the Philippines, and are often working in forgotten crises in countries like South Sudan and Democratic Republic of Congo.

Private donations mean they can send medical teams to help people
in unstable situations like the current conflict in Yemen, Iraq and Afghanistan, as well as to many other countries around the world.

It would mean so much to me and MSF if you donated.

Many, many thanks

eventName: Rentokil Initial UK helping make malaria no more
owner: Nick at Malaria No More UK
story:
To mark the end of Rentokil Initial's best ever fundraising year for Malaria No More UK and celebrate in style Rentokil Initial colleagues are invited to:

‘Pimp my Van’ and ‘Pimp my Desk’!

Rentokil Initial’s Fundraising Christmas Countdown

Please use this page to pay in your fundraising donations for Pimp My Van, Pimp My Desk and Pimp Your Manager. Please include details of your name or Rentokil Initial UK branch or business area with details of your pimping activity in the comments box.

Malaria is preventable and treatable, yet it claims the life of one child every minute.  As little as £1 can provide life-saving treatment to a child.  Through Pimp my Van and Pimp my Desk, Rentokil Initial UK staff are raising vital lifesaving funds for Malaria No More UK, which is helping to bring closer the day when deaths from malaria are no more.

charity.name: MALARIA NO MORE UK
story:
Hi everyone! My name is Shirley and I'm a 23 year old girl from London! In October of this year I took a trip to Ghana with my mum, to visit family, as we hadn't been back there in so long! It's such a wonderful place and I enjoyed my time there! But during my last few days, I contracted Malaria. It sort of crept up on me as I didn't even come across any mosquito bites, and I was taking anti-malarial tablets. I remember sitting with my family at an event, and feeling a little ill, and so I excused myself to the restroom, and I guess that's when the symptoms started. I was sick and felt so weak. When I explained this to my mum, and told her that I felt feverish (hot one minute, cold the next), she immediatly took me to the hospital. I saw the doctor and took some tests, and the results came back positive for malaria. I remember thinking, why me? Lucky for me, my mum was quick to make the decision to take me to the doctor. I recieved a few injections and medicine, and was told to finish the course of medicine over the following days. I was due to travel back to the UK that same day, and even though I was dreading the long plane ride, I just wanted to be home. It wasn't a pleasant journey as I cried half of the time, but when I got home, my mum put me in bed, and I was comfortable enough to rest. I was in bed for a whole week, but thankfully I recovered fully after that.

I can say that I am very fortunate to have been through that and recover, as some people aren't as lucky.

Malaria is a serious but preventable and treatable disease, but it claims the life of a child every minute. However, serious malaria cases can be reduced by providing mosquito nets, tests and medicines.

That's where a charity like Malaria No More UK comes in. I came across them and was very impressed with the work that they do to help people who may not have access to treatment or preventable measures for Malaria.

So I wanted to raise as much money as I could, with the help of my friends on the internet, to donate to their cause. If you're here reading this, thank you for visiting this page. And if you feel compelled to give, even as little as £1, I know that it would go a long way, and eventually help those people in need.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Every two minutes a child dies from malaria. And yet, it is preventable and treatable costing less than £1 for lifesaving medicine. By making a donation today, you’ll be helping us to protect millions of children and their families from malaria, saving lives and building better futures.

Susie has been raising money for Malaria No More https://www.malarianomore.org since 2016 and is continually dreaming up new challenges.

So far Susie has completed a number of running events (having only taken up running in 2016) in addition to organising various local events.  Her kids have even joined in by requesting that instead of gifts at their birthdays, guests at their parties consider making a small donation instead.

July 2017: 62 mile "Race to the Stones" two day running event.

August 2017: At the Tupton Tap first annual beer festival, Raffle; "Pestaurant".

Sept 2017: Susie's first half marathon - The Great North Run.

Nov 2017 - Ashover Christmas Fayre

Monies raised during 2017 resulted in recognition as 'Rentokil Initial's Fundraiser of the Year' for Malaria No More at the annual conference.

April 2018 - Susie's first marathon - The London Marathon

May 2018 - Organised the Fun Run at Ashover May Day

The next quest - Snowdon Triple Challenge - Saturday 22nd September.  10.5 mile cycle; 9 mile hike; 2.5 mile kayak.

Please dig deep to support this great cause.

charity.name: MALARIA NO MORE UK
story:
Malaria

Malaria is a widespread and deadly disease concentrated in equatorial regions--primarily in sub-Saharan Africa, 

In 2012,  207 million people became seriously ill from malaria and about 627,000 people died.  Most cases of malaria and most of the deaths caused by malaria occur in Africa.

The most vulnerable are persons with no or little immunity against the disease such as  young children, who have not yet developed partial immunity to malaria and pregnant women, whose immunity is decreased by pregnancy, especially during the first and second pregnancies

Every 60 seconds, malaria kills another child. Children are losing their parents. Parents are losing their children. People's lives are being torn apart at the hands of malaria. However we can stop this. By donating you can help end the ongoing fight with malaria. You can make a difference. They rely on supporters like you to help them make sure that life-savers like mosquito nets, medicines and malaria education reach families across Africa. Together, we can be the generation to make malaria no more.

How?

Raising funds will buy, deliver and hang long-lasting insecticidal bed nets (LLIN's). The disease is spread by mosquitoes at night, while people are sleeping. 

Hung over beds, these nets are extremely effective at killing the insects and preventing infection. Studies show that mosquito nets, when properly used, are still the most effective method at preventing malaria transmission:

What does your donation buy?

  • £1 saves a child's life
  • £10 is enough to buy, deliver and hang two mosquito nets
  • £25 is enough to train a volunteer to test for and treat malaria
  • £50 can buy, deliver and hang mosquito nets to help at least 20 children sleep safe
  • £100 can buy malaria tests and treatment to help 100 children who are sick

WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thames Water's executive team are raising money for WaterAid as part of our Thames Loves Malawi campaign. Recently, the execs visited Malawi to witness first hand the work WaterAid do and the importance of the money we raise.
In Malawi, WaterAid are working with the government, communities and partner organisations to share skills, knowledge and experience to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene part of everyday life.

Currently, 1 in 3 people don’t have clean water and 9.6 million people don’t have access to a decent toilet. 

The execs are raising money with the aim of building a virtual network and will be completing at least 12000 steps a day, highlighting how far some Malawians have to walk to get water.  

Here's what your donation could provide:

£24 Hygiene training

£60 Build a toilet

£72 Install 1km water pipe

£120 install a tap stand

£500 install well

£1000 buy hand pump

eventName: In memory of Dr M.A. Mullick
story:
Sadly, a few years ago our father Dr Mohammad Afzal Mullick, or Dr M.A. Mullick, as he was liked to be called, and our dearest mother, Shahzadi Malik, passed away. Our parents guided us on the right path, they dedicated their lives to caring and providing for us. We were blessed to have you as parents. The memories of our parents will be cherished forever in our hearts, every second, of every minute, of every hour, of every day. May their beautiful souls, rest in peace.

Both our parents worked hard and sacrificed to provide for us. Our father’s long career included serving nearly 25 years for the World Health Organisation (WHO), and involved living and working in countries such as Pakistan, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Somalia, Egypt, the UK and East Asia. The lifelong work and passion of our father involved helping people, by ensuring a clean drinking water supply as well as sanitation, were made available to countries both in the developing and developed world.

Our parents were generous people, they are no longer with us, but to honour their memory by supporting charities which were close to their hearts, we have setup a page to help carry on their charitable work. Several charities were dear to them including the Imran Khan foundation (http://www.imrankhanfoundation.org), as well as the Edhi foundation (http://www.edhiuk.org) and WaterAid (www.wateraid.org/uk).

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
J.P. Morgan BAR very much enjoyed meeting you in Cardiff for Act 5 of the Extreme Sailing Series 2014.

Thank you for taking the time to donate to WaterAid.

WaterAid is an international development organisation with a vision of a world where everyone, everywhere has access to safe water and sanitation. We work in 26 countries across Africa, Asia, Central America and the Pacific Region to transform lives in some of the world’s poorest communities.

Since 1981, we have reached 21 million people with safe water and, since 2004, 18 million people with improved sanitation. In 2011, WaterAid became J.P Morgan’s charity partner through the GeneroCITY employee engagement campaign. In 2013, we also became the official beneficiary of J.P Morgan’s Corporate Challenge in London.

J.P Morgan’s staff  have raised an incredible £230,000 so far and we thank them for the fantastic ongoing efforts and support.

www.wateraid.org

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I am travelling to Malawi for work and at the end of my trip will be taking part in a national initiative in Malawi called the Sleepover Challenge, an advocacy and fundraising campaign to support health care facilities with safe water, improved sanitation and good hygiene. Individuals are invited to spend a night at a public health care facility for a first-hand experience of the challenges degenerating maternal health services.

Part of the challenge is also to raise funds for WaterAid Malawi's work in the health care facility we will be visiting.

Thank you so much for your support! You can read more about the challenge below;

Malawi has one of the highest maternal and neonatal mortality rates in the world with studies attributing up to 20% of maternal deaths to sepsis and up to 400,000 cases of hospital acquired infections every year. Limited access to safe water, poor sanitation and poor hygiene are among key underlying causes.

In 2016, WaterAid studied 16 health facilities and found that they were all lacking in provision of safe water, improved sanitation and good hygiene like many others in Malawi. Despite safe water, improved sanitation and good hygiene being critical for health service delivery, it receives as little as 2% from the allocated health budget.

Safe water, improved sanitation and good hygiene in all health care facilities are necessary conditions for achieving SDG 6 and SDG 3 in Malawi. Unfortunately, the current state of affairs has become “normal” and those who make change possible are often detached from the unacceptable conditions in public health facilities.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

story:
﻿﻿We are privileged to live in a country where water is clean and reliable. This year Bristol Water completed a major project to lay a 30km resilience pipeline to make sure our water infrastructure will be strong for many years to come.

In other countries even the basics are difficult to achieve.

We are raising money for WaterAid to remember that clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty, and change their lives for good. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

------

From 14th-15th September I will be cycling, walking, and canoeing over 80 miles across Devon from Barnstaple to Dartmouth together with my colleagues to raise money for WaterAid and help provide those in need the most basic of human needs - clean water.

I will be covering all my travel, accommodation, and equipment costs so that 100% of your contribution will be donated to WaterAid.

Please help me achieve this by donating to my page.

***I will be making a video documenting my journey from start to finish where, for any amount donated, you will get a special "thank you" with your name immortalized in the credits***

Thank you!

Erik

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

By 2030 Wateraid wants everyone, everywhere to have clean water and toilets because these basic services are key to eradicating poverty. Through their partners, Wateraid has reached 19.2m people with safer water and 15.1m with toilets.

In September I shall be cycling in aid of Wateraid from Lusaka in Zambia, 480km to Victoria Falls. This is an enormous physical challenge for me as a very novice cyclist, the longest cycle I have done to date has been a London to Windsor cycle ride, at 37 miles, in October last year. We will be cycling on average 80km a day in approx. 30 degrees heat on largely off road tracks.

As part of my training I shall be cycling to work (a round trip of 30 miles) and taking part in the 46 mile Ride London event.

I am hugely grateful for any donation no matter how small!

Thank you very much for all your support.

Alice
title: Alice's Zambia Cycle for WaterAid

story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

I, along with a group of colleagues from Liberty Specialty Markets, will be cycling 500km from Lusaka to Victoria Falls in 8 days. Amongst the cycling, we will be visiting WaterAid projects to see the life changing work that WaterAid carry out first-hand - plenty of pics will be shared upon our return!

I have been involved with WaterAid as a charity for three years and the work that they do is life changing. The financial sums required to create a difference are not significant and therefore every penny of support that we can provide will make a GENUINE difference. Please dig deep and support this wonderful cause.

story:
Thank you for taking part in one of this year's auctions and for donating to this website.

We believe that clean water access is a basic human right. Almost 1,400 children die every day from diarrhoea due to unsafe water. 748 million people don’t have access to water – that’s more than the entire population of Europe. To change this, every April the entire Aveda network raises funds for WaterAid, an organisation that works to improve clean water access, hygiene and sanitation in some of the world’s poorest communities. Since 2010, we have raised over £507,000 for projects in India, Nepal, and Ethiopia, providing water access for more than 40,000 people.

Together with WaterAid we aim to raise £206,000 this year. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. story:
Dear Friends

While I was having a bucket of ice cold, and totally clean water thrown over my head for fun I realised that many people in the world can't even get safe water to drink, indeed millions in the world have no access to safe drinking water.

So rather than nominate someone else I thought I would challenge all my friends to see if we can raise enough money to build a well somewhere to provide safe water not for one morning, but for life.

Please help me meet that target

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Surely the most basic thing we should all have access to is clean water, right? That is an achievable goal, we could solve that problem.

  • 2.5 billion people in the world do not have access to adequate sanitation, one in three of the world's population.

  • 748 million people in the world do not have access to safe water. This is roughly one in ten of the world's population.

  • Half the hospital beds in developing countries are filled with people suffering from diseases caused by poor water, sanitation and hygiene.
Why donate to WaterAid in particular? They reached over 200 people an hour with safe water in 2013-14.

I think those are pretty good reasons.

story:
Thank you for visiting the 2014 J.P. Morgan Corporate Challenge Intern Team JustGiving page.

 

J.P. Morgan interns are taking on the challenge of running 5.6km in Battersea Park to raise as much money as possible for the official 2014 Corporate Challenge charity beneficiary: WaterAid.

 

Last year, funds raised for WaterAid through the J.P. Morgan Corporate Challenge were enough to reach more than 2,450 people, providing them with taps and toilets in some of the world’s poorest communities. This year, WaterAid has launched its “Everyone, Everywhere” campaign, which aims to see a world where everyone, everywhere has clean water, sanitation and hygiene by 2030.

 

If you are part of the J.P. Morgan Intern team, we encourage you to raise £15 by donating or fundraising with your friends and family. A donation of just £15 can give one person access to safe water and improved sanitation close to his or her home. J.P. Morgan will match the intern team’s donations up to a total of £1,500.

 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. JustGiving will not share your details with anyone or send you unwanted emails. Once you donate, your money will be sent directly to the charity. JustGiving will also make sure that Gift Aid (an additional 25%) is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer. That means more money for the charity.

 

Thank you for your support.

story:
Skydive Update

The original date was postponed due to bad weather.  I eventually jumped from the plane on the 11th April.

A huge thank you to everyone that has sponsored me.

http://www.nomenca.co.uk/News20.html

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hello!

Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. I am raising money for WaterAid as part of the Business4Life 2014/15 team.

On the 28th March I'll be jumping out of a plane at approx 10,000ft travelling up to speeds of 120mph.

I'm petrified of heights so signing up to do a Skydive probably wasn't the best idea, plus there is an added challenge of losing weight to meet the strict criteria set by the skydiving company.

Over the past year of Business4Life I have met some very inspiring volunteers and staff at WaterAid and seen that the donations made really do make a huge difference to the charity.

1 in 10 of the world's population still do not have access to safe drinking water and over 500,000 children die every year from diarrhoea caused by unsafe water and poor sanitation. 

WaterAid have set the target to achieve universal access to water and sanitation globally by 2030. Just £15 can provide one person with access to safe water.

Please help me to change lives by raising money to provide clean water and sanitation and help WaterAid to meet this goal.

Thank you for your support

Kat x

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Congratulations to Graeme Jones, the winner of the Supercar Track Day.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

RAFFLE TO WIN A SUPERCAR TRACK DAY

Simply make a £2 donation on this JustGiving page and the money will be sent directly to WaterAid.

For every £2 donated your name will be entered into the raffle to win a

supercar track day experience at a number of locations across the UK.

The more you donate the more chances you have of winning.

 

**However, please note that your donation cannot claim Gift Aid. Please

check your account settings if you are a registered user of JustGiving**

 

When you donate you need to UNTICK a box that declares ‘I’m not

donating on behalf of a group, company or someone and I’m not getting

a ticket, product or service in return for my donation.’

 

So you can be notified if you win after the draw on the 9th December,

please tick a box saying that it’s ok for me to see your email address.

  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Congratulations to Gerry Somers as the winner of the raffle for 3 x Manchester United tickets to watch the game against Chelsea at Old Trafford on the 26th October.

My next raffle will be launched soon...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This summer, we’re helping WaterAid to re-write the story for 130,000 girls around the world

What does it mean to be a girl?

Being a girl means something different to all of us. Perhaps it means to be happy, determined, carefree, feisty or particular? But for millions of girls around the world, to be a girl means something very, very different.

To be a girl without access to clean, safe water means your role of collecting water can stop you from going to school. It means back-breaking walks carrying heavy containers - often several times a day.

To be a girl without access to a toilet means there’s nowhere private to go to the loo and going in the open leaves you vulnerable to prying eyes.

To be a girl living without access to safe water and toilets means displaying incredible physical and emotional strength, day after day.

But it doesn't have to be this way.

This summer you can be part of something amazing. You can help WaterAid to change the story for girls around the world, giving 130,000 girls the future they deserve.

Until 9 September the UK Government will match every donation made to WaterAid’s ‘To be a girl’ appeal: doubling the difference for girls around the world.

story:
﻿﻿Dear Family, Friends & Colleagues,

I am embarking on an exciting journey for an extraordinary cause and I need all your help to reach my goal.  This September, I will be biking across Zambia for our charity at Liberty, WaterAid.  The reason why I am taking part in this incredible trip is that we often take clean water for granted when many people living around the world have never had this basic necessity.  Safe, clean water tranforms lives by unlocking better health, education and prosperity.  I'll be mountain biking 550 km across variable terrain over 6 days from Lusaka to Victoria Falls.  I'm looking to raise £10,000 and I need your help to reach my goal. 

Any contribution, however small, will be greatly appreciated.  I'll be writing a blog for the trip and will be sending some videos to make you all laugh at the state of us as we make our way across Zambia.

Thank you ahead for the support, encouragement and for giving communities in Africa clean water.

xx Mike

LECHARM is the global community arm of a charitable organisation and is a registered charity in its own right.  Its aim is to support the most disadvantaged people in our communities and help them live more independent and fulfilling lives.

LECHARM  supports educational, health and cultural project throughout the world and encourages environmental awareness, action and cooperation by individuals, organisations, corporations and governments. It also devises and manages projects and schemes for educational and environmental matters.

story:
My fundraising will be supporting WaterAid projects in Nepal and India, where extreme poverty is widespread and millions of people lack access to clean, safe water, improved sanitation and hygiene. As a result, water-related diseases are rife and child mortality is high. In Nepal, nearly two thirds of the population don’t have access to safe sanitation, and in India, over 186,000 children under 5 die every year from water-related diseases.

WaterAid works with local communities to change this by implementing sustainable, affordable and appropriate water, sanitation and hygiene solutions.

Hi everyone :-)

Happy New Year!

I have decided that one of my New Years resolutions is to give up my greatest love in order to raise money for charity...CRISPS. As most of you know, scoffing 3 packets of crisps a day and making nachos for one is my idea of living the dream. But now I've decided to give them up to raise money for WaterAid.

Here's the WaterAid website so you can have a look and see where your donations will be going :-) http://www.wateraid.org/uk

Going to leave the page open for the whole year, any size donation will be massively appreciated!!

Aditi xxx

PS - Everybody that donates is invited to my house on New Years Day in 2015 for a crisps party.

story:
On 9 September I'm running the Great North Run (a half Marathon) for WaterAid because water and sanitation should be a basic human right. 

I'm trying to raise about £300 which can be used by WaterAid to buy clean water tanks for five schools, or buy tools to dig a trench for a water pipe or hand washing stations for 10 families in Mozambique. 

As part of my training I've run  about 190km  so far with Nick. I'd really appreciate your support through a donation. 

Many thanks,

Janet 

-----

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Latest update  with  both off line and online  donations we have now raised £459 for WaterAid!! 

Thanks for taking the time to visit ourJustGiving page.

Throughout our lives we have always had access to clean water. We can turn on the tap at any time of day and be sure the water is good to use.

  • But 650 million people still live on our planet without clean water and 1 in 3 people don't have access to adequate sanitation. 
  • Diarrhoea caused by dirty water and bad sanitation is the second biggest child killer worldwide. A lack of clean water and toilets keeps girls out of school, stops women from working, and traps people in poverty.
  • Around 315,000 children under-five die every year from diarrhoeal diseases caused by dirty water and poor sanitation. That's almost 900 children per day.

WaterAid  tackles the reasons why millions of the world’s poorest people live without these most basic human services.

With hundreds of partners in civil society, government and the private sector, they deliver water, sanitation and hygiene to those most in need and make transformational change happen so that governments across the world provide all of their citizens with affordable, sustainable services.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thank you for your donation!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Ok, so while sitting at my desk in-between event calls where we were battling to stop the loss of millions of litres of water from one of our burst mains, I took the opportunity to have a cup of tea and read that day's e-brief. There was message about Water Aid. The irony of the importance that we put on our first-world problem soon became clear - well at least for duration of my tea drinking. It's not that our problems aren't real, or that going without water for a few hours isn't genuinely distressing for many but it is very, very different, and quite incomprehensible when compared to the one in nine people who are still living without clean water; or the one three without a decent toilet.

Water Aid's strategy is simple; to make water, toilets and hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere. 

When these basic needs are addressed, people can then focus on health, equality and education. Then the world can change!

If you want to be a part of this change then please sponsor me to cycle across Zambia from Lusaka to Victoria Falls as part of Team Thames, which includes Matt White, Lucy Pheiffer, Jose Varela and Simon Watson. Every pound raised will go to Water Aid.

Thank you so much for your support.

Rob Hales

P.S. The prospect of me cycling my current weight (I know my first-world problem) across the 536km/6 days journey, especially in potentially plus 30˚C heat is a little disconcerting. So when you see me please ask me 'how's my training plan is going?' - and please challenge me if my answer really isn't good enough!

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
When I left College I did Voluntary Service Overseas in Zambia  and was assigned to the government Department of Water Affairs. My work involved travelling around the bush measuring the flow of rivers in remote locations, including the borders with Angola and Congo. The information was used to assess water resources and develop infrastructure in the area. This bike ride challenge seems an obvious thing for me to do. 50% of the target funds go to WaterAid and I shall be paying the other 50% for flights, food and accommodation. So please give generously!

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Along with my crew-mates Lucy, Jose, Matt and Rob, 'Team Thames' will be cycling 536 kilometers across Zambia in six days to raise funds for WaterAid.

Before I explain the challenge and the aim, I know that many of you will be looking forward to seeing me go through a whole world of pain over the course of the next few months in order to get fit for the challenge ahead. Those who know me well, and certainly my Ground West colleagues at Thames, will know I'm partial to a sweet treat, so the first target is to get used to more than just walking to the canteen!

I'll be posting regular updates on here, and on my social media channels, with pictures and commentary, so you can see all the preparation ahead of what will be an amazing experience.

The challenge will take our team via mountain bikes, on and off road, through the friendly towns and villages of rural southern Zambia, passing farmland and sugar cane plantations, encountering all sorts of wildlife along the way before ending up at the famous Victoria Falls. Importantly, we’ll be visiting WaterAid projects en route and have a target of raising £4,400 in sponsorship each for the good cause.

There's a very long distance to travel, both in kilometers and in sponsorship - every single penny you donate will bring us closer to our destination, and will help to bring new life to some of the poorest areas of Africa though a supply of clean water. This will be an almighty challenge for all of us within the team, with long days in the saddle riding on dirt and sand tracks and intense heat of up to 29 degrees for six days back-to-back.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

story: Over 844 MILLION people worldwide do not have access to clean water close to their home. 2.3 BILLION people worldwide do not have access to a decent toilet of their own. 31% of schools worldwide do not have access to clean water. EVERY MINUTE a newborn DIES from a lack of safe clean water and a an unclean environment. Diarrhoea caused by dirty toilets and unclean toilets KILLS a child UNDER 5 every minute. Every year 443 MILLION school days are lost to water-related diseases and illnesses. It's a life necessity which is not present for billions of people worldwide which are affected on a daily basis. You can make that impact. Help others.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

In order to help create awareness for this charity, this September I will be cycling from Lusaka to Victoria Falls in Zambia, together with some of my colleagues from Liberty Specialty Markets. The route will cover approximately 550kms over 6 days and we will be staying in camps and guesthouses along the way.

 Normally, this would not be an issue for a seasoned road cyclist like myself (!), but this challenge will be on mountain bikes with knobbly tyres, ﻿over challenging terrain and with no team mates to draft behind or 'sticky bottles' to assist up the climbs!! Naturally, I am adding to my collection of 5 bikes to ensure I'm fully kitted out.

Any contribution, however small will be gratefully received. I will be writing a blog for the trip and there will be photographic and video evidence of our endeavours. Wish us luck!

Thanks
Sean

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
After months of planning, the last and MOST important reason why we are going on this 12 day trek on Mount Everest Base Camp this Easter is to help humanity.

The unique aspect of this trip is that we pay for it ourselves so any money raised goes directly to the charity of our personal choice.

We have chosen to fundraise for Wateraid charity to build wells.


Why water wells?

1. Each well produces 2,500 litres a day for 400 families. Amazing.

2. A neighbour & close friend Amir Lakha who passed away recently setup a scheme that each person gives £2 a month, individually little, together alot. He raised £1000s but after passing away a couple of months ago, it has been on pause. Let's restart the initiative again today.

3. My dad was born in Tanzania & it's important to give back to ones roots.

4. The dire need across Tanzania for clean drinking water is immense but the facilities are not there and people are dying daily. 3 children die every min due to dirty water. 

Reliable access to safe, clean water means that drinking, cooking, washing, watering crops and animals and making wudu no longer pose a risk of illness. This allows those less fortunate a chance to break free from poverty and transform their lives for years to come.

TOGETHER we can make a difference.

Khoram Majid is helping with the fundraising for us too.

Please donate any amount you can.

If you donate

£250 your name or deceased family member or business name will be engraved on a plaque on the well

£500 a flag with your business name or family or friend name will be held up on a flag for a photo on Everest Base Camp AND two business / family or friend or deceased names engraved on the well.

Pls donate generously.








Wateraid do great work in providing clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water.

water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
It's that time of year again! Last year I completed just the 125mile ride, this year I am doing the 200mile and then the 125mile ride on consecutive weekends. 

Some questionable weather and and an even more questionable training regime these last few weeks of summer are going to make it a real challenge!

Any donations to the wonderful work that Wateraid does would be appreciated not just by me but by all the people that it benefits. We take accessible drinking water and general sanitation for a given in the UK; unfortunately this is not the case in lesser developed countries around the world. Wateraid works globally to both deliver these standards to less fortunate communities, and also to teach and educate them so that they can support themselves in the future.

story:
Sadly last October my Mother In Law Joyce Patrick died. She was the most inspirational, kind, thoughtful, empathetic, funny, beautiful and fun loving person I have ever had the honour of meeting. Joyce was the best Wife, Mother, Grandma, Sister and Friend that anyone could ever wish for.

I would like to do the Great North Run, The Great North Swim and The Great North Cycle for The Great Joyce Patrick and to raise money for WaterAid.

I am truly thankful for any donations at all.I

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Hi!

I will be running in multiple events over the rest of the year, with the aim to run a marathon in 2019. Therefore I will be using this page as an ongoing fundraising effort through 2018, raising money for both WaterAid and Cancer Research - the separate Cancer Research page can be found here: https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/ben-print-run-2018-cancerresearch

If all goes well with scheduling and fitness, I aim to run in:

Leeds Half Marathon (13th May)

Wargrave 10k (10th June)

Checkendon 10k (17th June)

Marlow Twilight 10k (23rd June)

The Thames 10k (5th July)

Dinton Pastures 10k (12th July)

Wycombe Half Marathon (15th July)

Mapledurham 10k (4th August)

Burnham Beeches Half Marathon (12th August)

Maidenhead Half Marathon (2nd September)

Birmingham Half Marathon (14th September)

Bisham Half Marathon (22nd September)

Further races through 2018 into 2019



On a different note, WaterAid deals with problems experienced by a huge proportion of the Worlds population due to poor sanitation - which in this day and age really shouldn't be such a challenge. Some quick facts (sourced from WaterAid):

10% of the world's population don't have access to clean water

Every second, a newborn baby dies due to diseases attributed to poor sanitation

33% of the world's population don't have access to a decent toilet (2.3 billion people!)

Diarrhoea kills more children across the world than malaria, measles and AIDS combined - around 700,000 per year


Its very easy to become disconnected and desensitised with regards to global crises such as this in developing countries (I am just as guilty as the next person!), however just taking a step back and imagining a life where clean water and decent sanitation were unavailable it puts it into perspective. WaterAid believe clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. Therefore, I am also raising money for WaterAid to help further their positive impacts on reducing the impacts of poor sanitation and water insecurity in developing countries.


I hope to raise £200 for WaterAid

Thank you for visiting my page, and any donation large or small would be greatly appreciated!

story:
On 3rd August 2018, I will be trekking with 100 fundraisers from HSBC 100km within the Arctic Circle in Greenland. 

If I hit £1,000 I'll wear a toilet suit home on the train. That's 4 train changes. £2,000 I'll wear it home and back to work the next day. £10,000 I'll wear it for the trek! 

We won't have access to typcial facilities, everyone will be carrying their own equipment and sleeping rough in the middle of nowhere.  

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. 

Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. 

It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Every year since 2005, DPEA has entered a team for the WaterAid Challenge. This year, on 16 June, we are fielding our biggest (and cumulatively oldest) team ever!  (Tim Brian - leader, Frank and Rachel Cosgrove, Mike Croft, Malcolm Mahony, Janet McNair, Chris Norman, Martin Seddon and Andy Sikes)  And we are heading further south than ever - to climb the spectacular summit of Ingleborough in the Yorkshire Dales, where we will, hopefully, dodge the chasm of Gaping Gill and numerous pot holes on the way. 

We are once more hoping asking you to dig deep and sponsor us in aid of a very worthwhile charity that provides wholesome water supplies and sanitation to some of the world's poorest communities.  You can find out more about their work on their website at https://www.wateraid.org/uk/
title: DPEA walk for WaterAid

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
This is Het & Andrew. They love the mountains. They used to go hiking in the mountains all the time. Now they have kids. Three kids. And they go hiking occasionally, but it involves lots of bribery with sweets and cake, and certainly no photos of them together in the mountains. Only photos of the kids.

One day, Het said 'Team SES Water are doing the WaterAid mountain challenge. It's in Yorkshire - we have babysitters close by, we could spend the day together in the mountains and we can raise money for WaterAid. Shall we join?' and Andrew, amazingly, said 'Yes'.

Then, not very long ago, Het said, 'do you think we ought to start training for the mountain challenge? It's 24 miles and 1650m climb.' And Andrew said, 'well, about 10 years ago, when we were fit and had no kids, we attempted something similar and couldn't walk for a week afterwards. What could possibly go wrong?'

So, we've been training - probably not enough - but we are determined to raise much needed funds for WaterAid, so 9th of June, here we come!

Our kids have clean water, decent toilets and good health. So should everyone. Access to clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene allows people to live dignified, healthy lives, to break free from poverty and change their lives for good. Children are born healthier, they get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Yorkshire 3 peaks, we're coming to get you!

Find out more at https://www.wateraid.org/uk/get-involved/events/wateraid-mountain-challenge﻿﻿

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
1 in 9 don't have clean water close to home.
1 in 3 people on the planet don't have a decent toilet of their own. 

We are so lucky to live such comfortable lives so we're going to put ourselves through the challenge of cycling 100 miles (160km for all our European friends out there) to raise money for the great work that WaterAid does.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty, and change their lives for good.

100 miles would be challenge enough over a few days, but the mad people at RideLondon have planned a route to be completed in under 8 hours, including the picturesque but daunting hills of Surrey!

A bit of background:

  • You should sponsor Rebecca because she's only been on a road bike once before. We hope that her cycling genes, inherited from her grandpa who once rode from Germany to Rome, will eventually reveal themselves...
  • You should sponsor Max because his patience and intense coaching is what's going to get us across the finish line. 

We'll be posting updates of our fun training rides, so watch this space.

Your support means a lot to us.
title: Becca and Max #FinishThirst for WaterAid
pageSummary: We are pedalling 100 miles around London & Surrey because everyone deserves clean water and sanitation.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit the Sweco Leeds teams JustGiving page for WaterAid.

Sweco have previously undertaken the WaterAid Mountain Challenge numerous times. This year we are planning an alternative Mountain Challenge, where we plan to complete a big route in the Yorkshire Dales that includes at least one of the three peaks.

If you don’t want to sponsor us for the walk, then how about sponsoring us for braving the weather? Our track record is not good in this respect. Previously we have reached our chosen peaks on our hands and knees due to the storm-force winds and experienced constant, monsoon-style rain, returning with waterlogged phones to broken or submerged tents.  Just take a look at the photos at the bottom on this page!

Maybe it will be 4th time lucky, or maybe it won’t be? However, it turns out, you will be helping us support WaterAid, which transform lives by improving access to safe water, hygiene and sanitation in the world's poorest communities.

Thank you

Sweco Leeds team (Harriet Carlyle, Karen Scott, Lukasz Pietrzykowski, Matt Powell, Johnny Burns, Stuart Marsden, Chris Millward, Lucy Pietrzykowsk, Kathryn Nolan, Peter Grant, Christine Anderson, Caroline Ball and Stephen Hughes).

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
﻿﻿I will be trekking over 100km within the Arctic Circle in Greenland with 99 HSBC colleagues. With no access to a shower, 'proper' toilet or the outside world, we will be carrying all of our personal equipment and camping gear for 5 days trekking in one of the most remote places in the world. We aim to raise money to support the work of WaterAid.

Currently 663 million people (10% of the worlds population) live without safe water, 2.4bn people don't have access to adequate sanitation and over 800 children die every single day from diseases caused by dirty water and poor sanitation. WaterAid aims to transform the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people by improving access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene, and hopes to give everyone safe access to water by 2030.

Please dig deep and sponsor to support this worthy cause! All funds raised will go direct to WaterAid.

3 simple things, 3 specific goals - Water. Toilets. Hygiene. For all.

﻿
title: Gary's Arctic challenge for WaterAid

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
eventName: Bath to the Wash for WaterAid
story:
For the last few years I've been wondering how many miles I could cover by bike, riding from dawn to dusk on the longest day. However, as the training required for such a selfish ambition seems a bit unfair on my family, I was looking for a more valuable project to make this worthwhile.

During a pub conversation with a mate, the idea of a ride from Bath to The Wash, raising money for WaterAid, seemed to have a pleasing poetry to it. As I finalise details, I may even be able to include other places with water or ablution-themed names on the route, as long as I can cope with the extra mileage (the current route is in the region of 200 miles long). The exact date probably won't be 21st June, but it will be within a week of that date.

Only time will tell whether dusk finds me triumphantly surveying the Wash whilst filling my face with junk foods - or crying like a baby in a Cambridgeshire ditch.

I like WaterAid because clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and to grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living and run micro-businesses rather than wasting hours every day fetching water. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal - and it should be normal.
title: John's "Bath to the Wash for WaterAid" ride

WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Kevin Fitz-Simons was a hugely popular and respected industry
character who sadly passed away December 31st 2013, aged 53.

This event marks his passing and raises funds for two charities which would both have met with his approval.  Shelter (a charity dedicated to helping millions every year struggling with bad housing or homelessness) and WaterAid (an international charity who’s vision is of a world where everyone has access to safe water and sanitation).

It is an untimed fun event aimed at industry friends for both club and non club riders, it is a challenge for newcomers and a chill for superstars. 

The challenge itself will start at the Northern office of Kevin’s employer, A.C.Entertainment Technologies, and will follow the canal to where Kevin's earlier career started at Liverpool's Everyman Theatre.
title: Fitz-Simons Challenge 2018 - WaterAid
pageSummary: We are cycling 130 miles because it's in memory of Kevin Fitz-Simons.
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Kevin Fitz-Simons
pageSummaryWhy: it's in memory of Kevin Fitz-Simons.
Name: Fitz-Simons Challenge 2018 - WaterAid
ProfileWhy: it's in memory of Kevin Fitz-Simons.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water.

1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don’t have access to a decent toilet. We want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030. Together we can make that happen.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
The big day is here, Stantec UK are hosting a national WaterAid Cyclothon starting today - 23rd April 2018. This will be the launch of the Stantec UK wide “Be Active” campaign and is aiming to be the biggest WaterAid fundraising event of the year. Two static bikes are set up in the kitchen of our office for maximum embarrassment for each rider to cycle as far as they can in the time allocated. I have a late afternoon slot, just in time for people to have an afternoon coffee and be amused by the strange faces I pull whilst cycling! The aim is to go as fast and as far as possible - with a little inter office competition thrown in. And the reason for doing this; 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Thank you in advance of any amount you may feel able to donate.


Martin.
title: Martin's WaterAid Cyclothon 2018

story:
For the 25th annual Mountain Challenge the Wastewater Process Advisor's will be taking on the gruelling 25 mile event across the Peak District. This will involve around 12 hours of hiking up and down the hills and will require a lot of hard work and dedication to get us through the event as a team.

Wateraid have done some incredible work on improving the access to clean water and sanitation across the globe. From working in the water industry, this is something that certainly resonates with me and my colleges.

If you could help us along and reach our goal of £500 that would be massively appreciated! :)
