story:
We are aim to hitchhike around the world, relying only on the kindness of strangers and our own two feet - no public transport, taxis or flight at all. For the first leg of our journey, from Scotland to Senegal we are raising money for wateraid and really hope you can help support this amazing cause which is helping communities across the globe.

Follow our story at kindnessofstrangers.blog

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit the Robin James JustGiving page.

Robin James is helping Aveda UK support WaterAid during Earth Month 2016. To date, Aveda have donated an incredible £629,000 to the charity, supporting projects in Ethiopia, Nepal and, most recently, India. This year, Aveda will once again be fundraising for WaterAid’s project in India, which focuses on provided water, sanitation and hygiene education to women and young girls in a small village in Andhra Pradesh. Thanks to everyone for all your fantastic efforts in making this Earth Month the biggest one yet!

eventName: NCS The Challenge Real challenge Action Sutton
story:
We are Team Ward and we are working with Water Aid because we believe everyone should have easy access to safe, clean water. Girls would be able to get better education as they wouldn't have to travel miles to find water. By raising awareness and money, we can help people in places like Africa and Asia by building wells and taps.

This is important because it can help reduce chances of diseases like cholera and therefore deaths. More young girls can even get better education to have a more secure future.

story:
This year,  WaterAid is raising money for safe and clean water, taps and decent toilets for Rwanda. Their government plans to reach all communities by  2020..  With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.  Children are born healthier and they get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults.  Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Hello Dear friends and family,  Once again I am singing at the above event being held at 'The Scoop' at More London, Queen's Walk SE1 by the London Assembly building on the Thames on Sunday, 16th September, at 2.15 p.m..  This is an unmissable and uplifting outdoor choral performance of over 500 singers from choirs across the country, who come together for a powerful and evocative concert.

Whatever you choose to donate, no matter how small, goes towards  helping the above people in countries where water isn't taken for granted. Please come and enjoy the event as I would love to see as many people as possible. xxx

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
We take clean water for granted. And yet 844m people on this planet don’t have access to it. Sanitation is standard for us, too. And yet 2.3bn people in the world don’t have a decent loo.

On Sunday 23 September, with the aid of plenty of water, I’m cycling the Velo South 100-miler to raise cash to help WaterAid reduce those appalling numbers by a few. Please join me in this endeavour by donating ludicrous volumes of cash.

charity.name: WaterAid
eventName: Jacobs Shrewsbury Clyde Marine Challenge 2015 for WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Jacobs has a long history of fundraising for WaterAid, following the success of recent sailing events on the Clyde over £30,000 has been raised for WaterAid and other charities.

This year, for the first time, a boat from the Shrewsbury office will participate in the Clyde Marine Challenge.  We will sail from Largs on Friday 11th September for Rothesay then Tarbert braving fair weather or foul returning on Sunday 13th September.

WaterAid works in partnership with local organisations to help communities establish sustainable water supplies and sanitation close to home. However, with one in eight people worldwide are living without safe water – there is still much more to do.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thanks very much,

Andrew, Ali, Keith, Robert and Steve

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I recently spent time in refugee camps in Bangladesh and Iraq and have seen firsthand the importance of clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene in order for people to live a dignified and healthy life. WaterAid is running amazing projects around the world to support communities in accessing these things that we take for granted. For every pound donated to WaterAid, 77p go straight to projects. If you would like to know more, read up here: https://www.wateraid.org/uk/our-fundraising-promise

I am running the Berlin Marathon this year to raise awareness and funding for WaterAid's great efforts to continue. Any donation, big or small, in support would be greatly appreciated.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
In my job as a Clean Water Sampler for Anglian Water, I am reminded every time I take a treated Water sample for analysis at our Central Laboratories; just how lucky we are to have precious life sustaining drinking water at our kitchen cold water taps.  

SO I am doing the Kelda WaterAid10k run on Sunday 30/09/18, which is twice around the Swinsty Reservoir in North Yorkshire. ( I HAVE NEVER DONE A PUBLIC RUN OR RACE BEFORE) but I want to do my tiny bit to help raise funds which will help WaterAid achieve it's goal: Clean water decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

Hundreds of Water Industry specialists and thousands of volunteers work tirelessly to make a better life for those less fortunate than ourselves. This event is one of many annual fund raising initiatives to help WaterAid continue to improve the lives of so many.

Thank you so much for reading my story. It cannot be done alone so I am confident that together we can help to make a real difference. If you feel able to make a donation it will be truly appreciated by WaterAid and will boost my already strong motivation.

Thanks again

Jane x

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Every now and again its good to do something a little challenging and for a good cause.

On the 14/15th September, myself and 40 other fine colleagues will be Cycling, Walking, and Canoeing 80miles from North to South Devon across the beautiful but challenging moorland.

This year as a group we have selected Water Aid as a Charity - the rational is simple  and below. 

In addition.  Some of you will be aware of the challenges faced by my oldest friend and his family. He has received excellent support from Clik Sargent (and other charities) while his 6 month baby boy undergoes chemo for LCH. I want to say thank you to them helping one of my dearest friends. I will match 25% of whatever I raise here and donate to this marvellous charity.  Dig deep people - make me pay.

In case you are not aware of the brilliant mission of Water Aid its pretty simple, and very compelling.  Especially when you consider what we take for granted.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

P.s All donations will go to charity.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

This September, I will join the Accenture Strategy team for a 36-hour challenge to make our way from North to South Devon. We'll start off by cycling (60 miles), then hiking (10 miles) and finish off with canoeing (12 miles), all of this to raise money for WaterAid.

Access to clean, safe drinking water is often taken for granted - after all, it is so readily available! A broken shower or toilet in your home would cause frustration beyond belief, and how many of us would be willing to share those facilities with tens or even hundreds of people?

Having spent three months in Bangladesh on a water-related charity project, I strongly believe that there is so much we can do to ensure that everyone has access to safe, clean drinking water. So please, if you can, give generously! 

Yours,

Kadri

story:
We're learning the songs for Sing for Water West and raising money through donations for WaterAid.

Our 12 Sing for Water Singers are working hard to raise sponsorship from their friends and families - thank you so much to all those who have donated so far.  Other fundraising events have been a bring and buy sale at choir which members of the choir have organised, a cake sale in Pill precinct on Saturday 7th July 10.30 - 12.00, where the choir will be singing at 11am.  We are also having an end of term concert at Christ Church, Pill on Tuesday 10th July.  £5 on the door. Come along if you can!  

We are also having a disco with supper at Somerset Hall, Portishead on Friday, June 29th.  Tickets are £10 and are available at Morgan-Westley on Portishead High Street or e mail sergeant.wendy@gmail.com

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

story:
Hi Everyone!

In mid-September, a group of work colleagues and I are setting off to try to traverse Devon by foot, bicycle and canoe (they are excusing me the cycling bit because I'm not sure mid-challenge would be the best time to try to learn). Our charity challenges have been very successful in the past and I would really like to contribute to the fundraising goal of £25,000. 

Any support from you, my lovely friends and family, in achieving this would be very, very much appreciated. If you like hugs, I will give you a hug. If you are a crossfitter and don't like rowing, I will do your rowing for you. If you like chocolate cake, I will bake you one... you get the idea :)

I will let you know how it goes!

Sophia

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Hi, my name is Becky and I learned about Water Aid in school. The world provides plenty of water for everyone, but some people live in places where water is hard to find and dirty. We have plenty and we don’t understand the value of it as a result, we waste it. 3 children die per minute because of dirty water containing worms, parasites and mud, that’s 180 in the last hour. I would want someone to do something about it if it were me and so would you, that’s what Water Aid are doing. Please sponsor me a few pounds and you can help save lives. Every penny counts. Thank you.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
﻿﻿Every year I try to join a big challenge while helping a worthy cause. This year it is going to be a physical challenge! :)

Together with my colleagues I will cycle 60 miles across the Wales countryside, hike 10 miles through hills, and end in a dragon boat from North Devon to South.

The charity I have chosen to support this year is WaterAid because while water is the most important thing for humans' survival and health, there are still many places in the world where it is a luxury. 

C﻿lean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. This affects especially children. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier and get a chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive.

Help me raise some money for this worthy cause!

Thanks!

Alicia

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
With Ramadan approaching,  the BDO Islamic Network thought it would be a great idea to challenge people to take part in a dawn to dusk fast whilst raising funds for a great cause!

All proceeds will go towards WaterAid's fight against the global crises of poor water sanitation, hygiene and low prevalence of clean water across the globe.

We chose this fund because WaterAid offer life-saving work to those in poorer regions. We also felt that those taking part in the challenge will have a newfound love and appreciation of water!

More details of the project can be found at: http://www.wateraid.org/uk/what-we-do/the-crisis﻿﻿

And a big thank you to everyone at BDO taking part in the challenge or donating - your help is greatly appreciated!

If you have any queries, please contact Tahir.ebrahim@bdo.co.uk or Faheed.chaudary@bdo.co.uk

Thanks,

BDO Islamic Network

story:
I used to be able to run 10k three years' ago but after getting Achilles Tendonitis I could barely walk & my fitness obviously waned.  I have just started running again and thought I needed something to aim for and Wateraid is a charity close to everyone at Yorkshire Water's heart so thought the Kelda 10k would be a good start.  10k seems a long, long way at present as I've only been running 5k's so please give generously to see me pass out at the finish line!!

PS. Don’t forget 10k for my 4’10 and a quarter legs is like 20k :)

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life.

Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living.

On the 14th September Accenture Technology Strategy will bring a group of 35 Accenture adventurers together for our annual charity challenge. We will be weathering the elements over two days of physical activity, all with the aim of supporting two complimentary charities, Water Aid and Deworm the World.

We aim to cycle 60 miles across Wales, hike through the hillsides over 10 miles and finally paddle from the North of Devon to the South to raise as much as we can for each charity.

I am supporting Water Aid, so please donate whatever you can or wish the team well on this adventure!

Thank you. Ash Mehta

story:
For some reason, on a cold, wet, Tuesday night last December I signed up for the Great North Run, not thinking I would be successful.

I was. Bugger.

So, 10 years after running it for the first time as a fit and healthy 25 year old, I'm trying it again as a slightly overweight 35 year old. Originally I set myself the challenge of beating my 2008 time of 1 hour 52mins. As we get closer to the race, my goal has changed to just finish the race alive!

I've decided to run for WaterAid. Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our page

663 million people around the world dont have access to safe water.

As an employees of Northumbrian Water and a member of our WaterAid committee, this year I will be doing all sorts of fundraising for WaterAid.  

Our company has pledged to raise 1 million for WaterAid...and our chosen country is Madagascar. Therefore any donations you make on this fundraising page will go into this fundraising pot and can be directly attributed to WaterAid Madagascar. 

We will be going 'Just Water' for January. No tea, coffee, cocktails, wine or fizzy pop shall pass and it starts on 4th January....we fear we will discover quickly this really is not an easy task. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

I came back from Nepal earlier in the year with Giardia, and was off work for nearly 3 months (having been stupid enough to eat unwashed salad).  I lost over a stone and a half in weight, having been in the "normal" weight category to start with.  We tend to rather take our clean water supply for granted - imagine having no clean water for drinking, washing everything from ourselves to vegetables to clothes, and no clean toilets (holes in the ground can still be commonplace in Nepal).  Giardia causes cognitive problems and stunted growth in children (particularly in India, Nepal and some African countries), and I can now begin to understand the distress having it causes having had a particularly resistant strain myself and 8 lots of antibiotics (which I'm also fortunate to have had access to).  I'm now clear, and have left training for this event until later on as I needed to see whether I would be well enough, and my sciatica is quite bad at the moment.  But I am gong to dose myself up on painkillers, and go!!

Please donate towards someone, somewhere in the world less fortunate than ourselves, having a clean water supply.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
It's a long time since I've run, due to illness,my last long run was in 2012.

 I sponsored a little boy through Plan International, he died aged 3,due to no clean water or sanitation.

You may feel that it's these countries governments who should provide their citizens with clean water and sanitation and you'd be right. But these countries are often corrupt, unstable or war torn. I believe that with one small action at a time we can make a difference. We are very privileged, clean water from our taps, sanitation, we even flush our toilets and water our gardens with drinkable water! No one should die due to a lack of clean water, but millions are everyday, mostly children.

Let's make a difference.


Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.name: WaterAid
eventName: Woofy and Sulli's Yorkshire 3 peaks Challenge
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Upon reading an article about a Zambian woman carrying 20 litres of water nearly 4 miles (everyday), we propose to carry two 20 litre bottles (over 20kg) of water over the distance of over 24 miles and climbing over 3 of Yorkshires highest peaks which is over 5200ft of ascent. 

With an estimated time of around 10 hrs to walk it and considerable weight in our backpacks, we hope to raise awareness and some cash for a very important world cause.

Your sponsorship is most grateful. 

Thank you

Woofy and Sully

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Claret Civil Engineering Ltd have supported Water Aid for many years. Following Andy Gibbons (Claret's MD) recent visit to Nepal as part of Water Aid 2018 he decided that we should do more to help.

Andy saw first hand the fantastic work that Water Aid are doing in 1 of the 34 countries in need of help.

This September three Claret employees (Luke Allen, Kevin Manning & Tom Dougan) will be joining the Water Aid Cycle Event. The 150 mile ride starts in Lincoln riding through Rutland arriving in Pitsford for a nights stay (105 miles approx.) Following a well earned rest the trio will get back on the saddle and finish the ride back to Rutland (45 miles).  

Please help them raise as much money as possible because clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without these things people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With something as simple as clean water and sanitation they can break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. Not only do these children get the chance to go to school but they have a chance to grow up and become adults. Women and men get to earn a living an whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal, and it should be for everyone.

For more information on the good work Water Aid do, please visit https://www.wateraid.org/uk/

Thank you

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
The Great British summer heatwave has been one to remember however it has made training for the Great North run even harder than it would usually have been. 

Instead of sipping on a refreshing drink in a sunny pub garden I have spent many evenings running up and down the banks of the Thames in 30 degree heat.

However at the end of each run I have had clean water readily available to me, where many people do not. As a lot of you will already know, WaterAid is doing everything it can to get water to everyone, everywhere by 2030. And every step of every training run I have done is worth it knowing who I am trying to help. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

story:
Kevin Moody (Kev) was a mechanic at Littlecoats WTW in Grimsby and was a well known and popular guy who had an infectious smile and relentless optimism. Unfortunately after a 10-month battle and intensive treatment for a inoperable brain tumour, he passed away in October 2017 aged 52 leaving a wife, family and many friends and colleagues. Those who knew him said he was renowned for his energy and positive attitude for life and his love for cycling was well-known. He completed the Lincoln 150 on more than one occasion, one year completing the journey down to Pitsford on a pristine vintage ‘Viscount’ bike. The WaterAid team have been given permission from his family to rename the Lincoln 150 ride to the ‘Kev Moody 150’ in memory or this much loved and respected colleague. For more information on Kev and his passion for life please visit: https://www.grimsbytelegraph.co.uk/news/grimsby-news/tributes-popular-grimsby-mechanic-who-703204

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. story:
Last year, my school friend Jane and myself ran the Great North Run for the first time. If we could go back in time to our teenage selves, I’m not sure we would have believed  that it was possible. It was such a wonderful and inspiring experience. That great hub of people all heading towards South Shields, all with their own reasons for doing it. It was very humbling, and wonderful to be a tiny part of such a big event. We felt proud of our region, and very happy to be part of it. People tell you how the local support along the route is unwavering, but it really is, it’s marvellous. 

This year we are very proud to be raising money for Water Aid. This is why. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Access to clean drinking water is a basic human right that every individual should have and unfortunately this isn't the case for far too many people.

Every minute a newborn dies from infection caused by lack of safe water. Diarrhoea caused by dirty water kills a child under 5 every two minutes. 

Education is critical for breaking the cycle of poverty and yet over half of the world's schools lack access to safe water and sanitation facilities. Lack of clean water has serious effects on students' academic performance and attendance rates. The lack of safe water can cause even the best students to lose momentum as they deal with stomach pains and diarrhoea from disease and hunger.

Lack of Water = Lack of Equality

For girls, the situation is especially troublesome. It is typically the responsibility of the women to fetch water thus limiting their access to both education and business opportunities. Think about it: everyday, women and young girls carry more than 40 pounds of dirty water from sources over 4 miles away from their homes. This leaves little time for education which is critical to changing the long term prospects of developing nations.

With the many additional burdens that a lack of clean water brings, education simply becomes less of a priority. This sets up an unfortunate cycle of poverty and inequality as without a proper education, there is little chance of improving one's situation later in life.

I am running the Bristol half marathon in September in order to help change this. Please support me by donating whatever you can. Anything would be greatly appreciated and would help make such a difference to many lives.

Annabelle x
title: Annabelle's campaign for clean drinking water
pageSummary: Running the Bristol Half Marathon because everyone has a right to clean drinking water
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
pageSummaryWhy: everyone has a right to clean drinking water
Name: Annabelle's campaign for clean drinking water
ProfileWhy: everyone has a right to clean drinking water

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Did you know that every minute, a newborn baby dies from infection caused by unclean water and the environment?

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified and healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their future for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

What am I doing? 
I will be taking part in a mini trekking expedition to 3 of the tallest mountains in the UK to complete the National Three Peak Challenge. Please help me reach the finish line! :) 

Why your donation matters
Every donation is a step closer towards giving more people access to a basic human right – water. It’s worth more than silver and gold, yet it’s so easy to forget how precious water really is to our survival.

A Big THANK YOU!

If you donate, I will be ever so grateful because I know that completing this challenge will be worthwhile, and you will be on this journey with me. 

Feel free to “splash out” generously – pun intended.

Thank you so much for stopping by and for your donation!

Victoria

https://www.wateraid.org/uk/

story:
We've had a brief Hiatus since conquering Snowdon in 2015, but we're back for more!! 

On the 8th September 2018 Seb and myself are attempting a 105 mile Coast to Coast crossing of Scotland. This entails 21 miles of running, 83 miles of cycling (on and off-road) and 2 miles of kayaking... All at the mercy of the Scottish elements, into the prevailing wing and with 2 miles of elevation to contend with..!! Its going to be a long day..

We'd love your support and would encourage and gratefully welcome financial gifts to a superb charity. Water Aid aims to ensure clean and healthy drinking water to be made available for all, please help if you can..

Seb and Hugh

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
We're learning the songs for Sing for Water West and raising money through donations for WaterAid.  Our 23 Sing for Water Singers are working hard to raise sponsorship from their friends and families - thank you so much to all those who have donated so far.  Other fundraising events are a raffle which members of the choir have organised, a concert at the Folk Hall where we practise on Monday 9th June at 11am where there will also be a cake sale.  Come along if you can!  

We are also having a disco with supper at Somerset Hall, Portishead on Friday, June 29th.  Tickets are £10 and are available at Morgan-Westley on Portishead High Street or e mail sergeant.wendy@gmail.com

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water. Every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.Together we can change lives.

Laura & Mahben

story:
We're taking part in the Royal Parks Half Marathon for WaterAid. Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights.

I (Laura) am lucky enough to be able to visit some of the communities in which we work and I have seen first hand the devastating impact that a lack of clean water and decent toilets can have. 

We've set up a joint fundraising page because while running 13 miles will be a MASSIVE undertaking for me, it is something Pie does for fun. She has offered to run alongside me and offer supportive words - for two hours. TWO HOURS. Now that deserves payment, one way or another.

Also - whoever donates the most money can choose Pie's costume.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
This year I’m running 1,000 miles (1,600km) for Water Aid to raise £750 - a bargain at just 75p a mile and twice the distance I ran last year!

Clean water, sanitation and hygiene are a basic human right, not a privilege. Water Aid help millions of people in 28 countries to achieve this right.

I’ll be running multiple 10k’s & Half Marathons, four Ultra Marathons and the Berlin Marathon to help get me to my massive target.

Every £1 you donate will enter you into a raffle to win prizes from a collection worth over £300!

Key Events:
- Multiple 10k’s
- Punk Panther 50k Ultra
- Canalathon 50k Ultra
- Burnsall Trail Half Marathon
- Leeds Half Marathon
- Pieces of 8 Trail Half Marathon
- 2 races & 240km in 8 Days! [Endure 24 Solo & IoW Ultra]
- Yorkshire Three Peaks
- Berlin Marathon

story:
Liebe Geschäftspartner, liebe Freunde,

﻿wie Sie/ihr vielleicht bereits wissen/wisst, unterstützt Liberty Specialty Markets seit vielen Jahren Hilfsprojekte in der Dritten Welt. Dieses Jahr unterstützen wir ein Trinkwasserprojekt in Sambia, Südafrika.

Das Besondere ist, dass ICH persönlich etwas dafür tun muss (darf) - und Sie/ihr können/könnt mich dabei unterstützen. Ich werde Sambia im September mit dem Fahrrad ca. 500 KM erkunden und diverse geförderte Projekte persönlich vor Ort besuchen. Das Projekt wird über WaterAid durchgeführt und gefördert.

SIE/IHR können/könnt mich unterstützen! Mit einer Spende haben/habt Sie/ihr die Möglichkeit, ebenfalls einen Beitrag zu leisten!

Sobald das Spendenziel erreicht ist, beginnt für mich die Tour durch Sambia!

Vielen Dank für Ihre/eure Unterstützung!

Ihr/euer Michael Kroll

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Personally I would only ever raise money for a charity that spends most of its donations in the developing world, as that's where need is greatest.

WaterAid are one such charity, that help poor communities establish sustainable water supplies and toilets, they work across the world including Africa and India, where I have seen first hand the levels of poverty the people there have to endure.

I would really appreciate it if you could spare a few pounds for this great charity and you really would be making a difference.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
my name is Hannah and I was introduced to water aid when I walked into a coffee shop and found a magazine that said water aid. I had been so interested. In most developed countries we have fresh clean water everyday. Some adults and children have to drink filthy water. These people have to walk for miles to get just a bucket of infected dirty water. Over 2,000 people are dying everyday because they are drinking this horrible water. So people who are in developed countries should stop taking 8 or 9 bottles a day and only taking the first cold sips. Stop and think about others please.

eventName: Sing for Water at Totally Thames
story:
Crystal Palace Transition Town Choir are supporting Sing for Water this year.  Members are learning a special repertoire of songs which will be performed at 
Sing for Water London
Sunday 16th September 2018, 2.15pm
The Scoop, More London, Queens Walk, SE1 2DB
All welcome to come and enjoy a wonderful, riverside spectacle as choirs from across the country come together to raise their voices for WaterAid's life-saving projects in Rwanda.  

It only costs £15 to give one person access to clean water for life so every note sung and penny raised makes a difference.

More info at 
http://totallythames.org/event/sing-for-water
https://www.wateraid.org/uk/get-involved/events/sing-for-water-london

About Sing for Water
Sing for Water was initiated by composer Helen Chadwick as a project to raise money for WaterAid at The Thames Festival in 2002. Mass choral events now take place across the country and have raised over £1 million for WaterAid's life-saving projects providing clean water, hygiene and sanitation in the world's poorest communities. 

About WaterAid
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Why I'm doing this:
Four years ago I made a promise to myself to get fitter and healthier, so that I could stand on a pair of scales and not have the display between my feet simply say "ERROR".

Unfortunately I was unable to keep that promise. Although I did the Darlo 10k that year, it took me over an hour and a half because lack of proper training in the weeks leading up to it meant I walked more than I ran.

This year, with the help of my friends and colleagues from Edward Robertson, I'm on the charge again. I'm eating healthier, I'm running longer, and I'm working harder. This time, I'm going all the way to the goal - and beyond.

I've chosen the Kelda 5k as my first event because it arrives at a good time in my plan - I should be comfortably up to running 5k by this point. I'll get a good time, cross the line with a smile on my face, and raise some money for charity. It also helps that a friend of mine is the race director this year, and frequent campaigner for WaterAid - wonder if he's running it as a tap again? ;)

So please help me beat my first goal by donating whatever you can - thank you.

Why WaterAid are doing this:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. 

It sounds normal - and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Running gives you time to think. 

One of the simpler things I often think about while running is wow, I'm thirsty! 

Luckily for me and most people in the Global North, access to water is not a problem and we take it for granted.  I don't go thirsty for long.

Not everyone is as fortunate.

I'm combining my desire to run Berlin Marathon with the goal of raising money for WaterAid.

WaterAid help communities around the world make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene a normal part of everyone's daily life.  As it should be. 

Please consider sponsoring me to raise money for WaterAid because they have been kind enough to give me a charity place in a race I would otherwise not be able to run.

I'm also targetting a sub-3:00 hour marathon.  If you'd like to tie your donation to a "bonus" if I achieve this, please do so! 

My PB at the moment is 3:11:16, so I have some way to go...

Many thanks.

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
ISG is supporting CARE International to help people find routes out of poverty.The money we raise will help CARE fight poverty and injustice in more than 80 countries around the world. CARE also delivers emergency aid to survivors of war and natural disasters, and helps people rebuild their lives in the aftermath.

Every donation counts and at least 83% of all donations is spent on CARE’s poverty fighting programme so please dig deep and donate now! 

As part of our global CSR initiative in raising money for our partner charity, CARE, we are raising money by seeking sponsorship for our staff to run a variety of distances in the 100 Plus Out Runner race. We have 32 staff running a combined distance of 260km.

We would like to seek your commitment to make a difference by sponsoring our staff for every km they successfully run. Please donate online or email outrunner@isgplc.com for more information on donating in cash.

With your generous support, we can all make a difference. 

- - - - -

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Instead of being glued to a sofa this Easter holiday I’m going to be walking 10,000 steps (about 5 Miles) everyday for a week (16th - 22nd April) as part of Care International UK’s ‘Walk in Her Shoes 2018’ campaign.

I thought my commute to university was time-consuming, but women all over the world don’t even get a chance of an education because of the time they must spend everyday walking to collect water for their family. Often this water isn’t even safe to drink or use. 

By sponsoring me ‘walking in her shoes’ you can help Care International’s initiative to build sanitary water pumps and wells in remote villages worldwide, helping these women participate in education, become employed and break out of the cycle of poverty.

Thank you for looking at my page, I’m so grateful for anything you are able to donate towards this cause!

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story: This December I will be shaving my head to fundraise for Care International, a charity that works around the globe to save lives, defeat poverty and achieve social justice, with a special focus on women and girls to fight for their equal rights and opportunities! Furthermore, the hair I shave will be donated to The Little Princess Trust to create free wigs for children and young adults who have lost their hair due to cancer treatments and other illnesses. Care International work alongside people and communities on long-term programmes, that tackle the underlying causes of poverty to deliver lasting change! With at least 85p of every £1 going directly toward fighting poverty, and only 15p going toward fundraising and support, Care International is a phenomenal charity whose long-term goals makes EQUALITY SEEM POSSIBLE! After speaking with the charity, I am hopeful that by October I will be fundraising for a specific appeal surrounding women’s maternal and sexual health in developing countries. After recent research surrounding gender-biased neglect, rape, child brides, domestic abuse, female genital mutilation, death due to childbirth/miscarriages/abortions and so much more, this is a subject I find personally challenging and upsetting. Every woman deserves control over her own body, to understand her own body, and to be looked after and supported both medically and emotionally when needed. With Care’s top aim for 2020 being that 100 million women and girls exercise their rights to sexual, reproductive and maternal health and a life free from violence I thought there was no reason not to start fundraising NOW! Any donation will be MUCH APPRECIATED! If you aren’t able to donate, or just want to do more, please get in contact with me to help fundraise, spread awareness, or share your own fundraising tricks and tips with me!

eventName: Stairs And The City Women's Stair Climb
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am climbing stairs to support women and families displaced by war. Women rebuild the community and hence the men also benefit in the longterm:  the family is the future. We are seeing too many images of families being displaced under the unimaginable horror of conflict. 

I will be attempting to climb 48 flights of stairs (@1250 steps) at the Leadenhall building, as fast as I can. Please sponsor me to spur me on to help to make a difference. 

Every little bit helps, and so this is my ‘bit’.Thank you for your support.

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

CARE fights poverty and injustice in 86 countries around the world to help the world’s poorest people find routes out of poverty. CARE also delivers emergency aid to survivors of war and natural disasters, and helps people rebuild their lives in the aftermath.

CARE’s mission is to create lasting change in poor communities and put money where it is needed most: 94 pence in every £1 goes towards our poverty fighting programmes. That’s one of the highest rates among all the UK aid agencies.

We particularly like the work of Care International because its work ranges from providing education and shelter through to providing medicine- it is not restricted to one type of support. Additionally, it is not prejudiced in the type of people it helps; regardless of sex, race, gender, and religion it aims to help all those in extreme poverty.

We are particularly interested in the work that they are currently doing for Syrian refugees. The Syrian crisis is worsening day by day and I think its paramount that individuals and charities do all that they can to alleviate the suffering experienced. We also think that their work for one-off crisis' such as the Phillipines hurricane is significant; providing humanitarian aid quickly and efficiently for events such as these, is paramount to saving lives.

Your donations will go to those in need of education and to programmes helping small businesses, so communities can, in the long term, can get on their own feet. They will also go to those needing medication, water and shelter supplies so that in the short term suffering and poverty can be diminished. We also think that the way they work with businesses and Governments ensure that you donations definitely go to the right places.

Visit

http://www.careinternational.org.uk/ if you want any more info!

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
I am fundraising for CARE International whose work around the globe supports vulnerable people living in poverty, affected by war or natural disaster. CARE provides emergency food and shelter, and helps communities create sustainable solutions to poverty. 
Women and girls are most affected by poverty, so CARE puts them at the heart of what they do and works to tackle issues of inequality and support them to reach their full potential. Your sponsorship will help CARE reach more people and achieve a world of hope, tolerance and social justice.

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Every day thousands of women and girls, all over the world, have no choice but to walk many miles to fetch water for their families. Water that is often dirty.
Their daily routine deprives them of the chance to have an education, a job, and traps them in a cycle of poverty.
The money you raise can help build wells and water pumps closer to rural communities so that women and girls don’t have to spend their days walking for water, and can plan for a better future.
